titleStmt.title:
THE VVEAKEST goeth to the Wall.
As it hath bene sundry times plaide bu the right honourable Earle of Oxenford, Lord great Chamberlaine of England his seruants.

publicationStmt.p: LONDON Printed by Thomas Creede, for Richard Oliue, dwelling in Long Lane. 1600.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Prologue King of Fraunce Lodowick Duke of Bullen/Bulloigne Mercury Duke of Anjou Gentleman 1 Gentleman 2 Barnabie Bunch Citizen 1 Citizen 2 Citizen 3 Lord Epernon, French General Sir Nicholas, Vicar Jacob Van Smelt, Flemish host Oriana, Lodowick's wife Diana, Lodowick's daughter Hernando de Medina, Spanish General Don Ugo de Cordova, Spanish Lieutenant Souldier 1 Souldier 2 Emmanuel Duke of Brabant Leontius Frederick/Ferdinand Odillia, Emmanuel's daughter combined speech Shamont Nuntio Messenger Villiers the Merchant

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following:

body.stage: THE VVEAKEST goeth to the Wall

div1.stage: After an Alarum, enter one way the Duke of Burgundie, an other way, the Duke of Aniou with his power, they encounter, Burgundie is slaine. Then enter the Dutches of Burgundie with young Fredericke in her hand, who being pursued of the French, leaps into a Riuer, leauing the child vpon the banke, who is presently found by the duke of Brabant, who came to aid Burgundie, when it was too late.

sp.l: The Duke of Aniou fatally inclined
Against the family of Bullen, leads
A mighty Army into Burgundie,
Where Philip younger brother of that&H62; house
Was Duke: whose power unequal with his foes,
Received the foil, and being slain himself,
The soldiers afterwards pursue his wife:
She flying from the City, took with her&H6;,
Her&H2; pretty Nephew, Lodwicks tender son,
Brought up&H5; and fostered by&H4; his uncle Philip,
And in&H4; her&H2; flight to&H9; scape the bloody hands
Of those that&H61; followed, leaps into a River,
And there untimely perished in&H4; the flood.
The little Fredericke left upon&H4; the shore,
The tardy Duke of Brabant all too late,
That&H61; came with succour to&H9; relieve his friend
Espies, and ignorant of whence he was
Maintains and keeps him, till he came to&H4; age:
Of him, his fortune, and his fathers woes,
The Scene ensuing, further shall disclose.

div2.stage: Enter King of Fraunce, a noble man bearing his Crowne, and an other his hatte, staffe, and Pilgrimes gowne, with them conuersing Duke Aniou, and Lodwicke, Duke of Bullen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How long shall I entreat? how long my Lords,
Will&H1; you detain our&Hrp; holy Pilgrimage?
Are not our&Hrp; vows already registered
Upon&H4; the unvalued Sepulchre of Christ,
And shall your malice and inveterate hate
Like&H4; a contrarious tempest still divorce
Our&Hrp; soul, and her&H2; religious chaste desires?
If it be treason to&H9; attempt by&H4; force,
To&H9; take from me this earthly Crown of mine,
What is it when you study to&H9; deprive
My soul of her&H2; eternal Diadem?
O did you but regard my just demand,
Or would like&H4; subjects tender your Kings zeal,
You could not choose but entertain a peace.
Why frown you then? why do your sparkling eyes
Dart mortal arrows in&H4; each others face?
Am I a friend, and can I not persuade?
Am I King, and shall I not prevail?
Aniou be pacified, and Bullen leave
To&H9; feed thy swelling stomach with contempt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your grace doth know (with pardon be it spoken)
My wrongs are such, as I have cause to&H9; frown,
Nor can you blame me if I loath his sight
That&H61; was the butcher of my brothers life.
In&H4; Burgundie what slaughters did he make?
What tyranny left he unpractised there?
Philip suppressed, did not their bloody hands
Extend to&H4; women and resistless babes?
Amongst the rest, was not the Duchess drowned?
And that&H62; which&H61; draws continual floods of tears
From these mine eyes: and daily doth assail
My feeble heart with never dying grief,
Miscarried not young Fredericke my son?
Ah was not he untimely by&H4; their means
Cut off, that&H61; should have comforted mine age?
Poor boy, whose piteous speaking eye
Might have been able to&H9; have turned the hearts
Of savage Lions: yet they spared him not.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Ah speak no&H2; more of Burgundy's decease,
Nor wake the quiet slumber of thy son,
But with the gray decrepit hairs of thine
That&H61; are expired since Fredericke was entombed,
With his dear Aunt amidst the liquid waves,
Let slip the memory of that&H62; mishap,
And now forget it, and forgive it too.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Although I must confess the least of these
Incumbent evils, is argument enough
To&H9; whet the bluntest stomach to&H4; revenge:
Yet that&H3; your highness may perceive my mind
Doth savour of mildness and compassion,
And that&H3; the Bullen Duke may never be found
To&H9; be a Traitor to&H4; his Kings command,
There is my dagger, and I will&H1; lay my hand
Under the foot of Aniou where he treads,
And I will&H1; do it to&H9; deserve your love.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: We&Hrp; thank thee Bullen for&H4; thy kind respect,
But he that&H61; should be foremost to&H9; set ope
The gate of mercy, and let friendship in&H5;,
Upon&H4; whose head redounds the whole reproach
Of all these injuries, swollen big with ire:
Stands as an Out-law still upon&H4; defiance.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I must dissemble there is no&H2; remedy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Look Aniou here, and let his summers brow,
Thaw the hard winter of thy frozen heart.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Dread sovereign, Aniou likewise doth submit,
And with repentant thoughts for&H4; what is past,
Rests humbly at your Majesty's dispose.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Then take the Duke of Bullen by&H4; the hand,
And treading former hatred under foot,
Wherewith your houses have been still oppressed,
Like&H4; subjects of your King be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There is my hand Lodwick, the hand of him,
That&H61; thought to&H9; have imbrewed it in&H4; thy blood,
But now is made the instrument of peace.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And there is mine, with which&H61; I once did vow,
To&H9; sacrifice thy body to&H4; pale death,
But now I do embrace thee as a friend.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The like&H0; do I, but to&H4; another end,
For&H3; Lewis no&H2; sooner shall depart from hence,
But straight new deeds of mischief I will&H1; commence.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: This joys my soul, and more to&H9; let you know
How pleasing this retreat of peace doth seem,
Till my return from Palestine again,
Be you joint governors of this my Realm,
I do ordain you both my substitutes:
And herewithal bequeath into your hands,
The keeping of the Crown: myself adorned
With these habiliments of humble life,
Will&H1; forward to&H9; perform my promised vow.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The God of heaven be still your highness guide.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And help to&H9; thrust thy partnership aside.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Lodwick, the love that&H61; thou dost bear to&H4; us&Hrp;,
And Mercury, the allegiance thou dost owe,
Now in&H4; my absence both of you will&H1; show.
So&H3; leaving and relying on&H4; your trust,
I bid farewell, remember to&H9; be just.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Brother of Bullen: so&H52; I will&H1; call you now.
For&H3; why, this birth of new authority
Will&H1; have it so&H52;, let me entreat your grace
That&H3; you will&H1; excuse my sudden haste from hence.
I have some urgent cause of great affairs,
That&H61; call me to&H4; the country for&H4; a while,
But long it shall not be ere I return.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: At your good pleasure he is brother of Aniou,
Yet let me tell you that&H3; the jealous work
By&H4; this our&Htp; separation will&H1; misjudge.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Not for&H4; so&H51; short a space, on&H4; friday next
I mean God willing to&H9; revisit you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Adiew my Lord: the strange events that&H61; time
In&H4; his continuance often brings to&H9; pass:
Not two hours since I would have sworn he lied,
That&H61; would have told me, Aniou and myself,
Should ever have been heard to&H9; interchange
Such friendly conference but my word is past,
And I will&H1; keep my covenant with the King.
God save your honour.
Health to&H4; the Duke of Bullen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Gentlemen you are welcome, come you with news?
Or have you some Petition to&H4; the King?
A suit my Lord, which&H61; should have been preferred
Unto the King himself, but being gone
Upon&H4; his Pilgrimage before we&Htp; came,
The power now to&H9; do us&Htp; right remains
Within your hands: whom as we&Htp; understand,
His grace hath made Vice-regent of the Land.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What is your suite?
This paper will&H1; unfold,
If please you take perusal of the same
O I remember now, it is to&H9; have
A Patent sealed, for&H4; certain exhibition
Given by&H4; his highness for&H4; your service done
Against the late invasion of the English.
True my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well I will&H1; do you any good I can:
But Gentlemen, I must be plain with you,
I am but the half part of that&H62; authority
Which&H61; late you spake of: for&H3; with me is joined
The Duke of Aniou, equally possessed.
And he even now departed from the Court,
But when he doth return, you shall be sure
To&H9; be dispatched.
When he returns my Lord?
That&H62; will&H1; not be I fear, till angry war
Hath brought destruction on&H4; some part of Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How say you that&H62;? till angry war hath brought
Destruction on&H4; some part of Fraunce, why so&H52;?
Because my Lord, in&H4; secret he hath levied
A mighty power, which&H61; since, as we&Htp; are told,
Lying not far from Paris, had in&H4; charge
As on&H4; this day to&H9; meet the Duke at Mullins.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A town near neighbouring on&H4; my territories:
It is even so&H52;, this proud dissembling Duke
Made our&Htp; reconcilement but a colour
To&H9; cloak his treason till the King were gone,
And now his hollow and perfidious dealing,
As when the turf the Adder lurked in&H5;
Is shorn away, begins to&H9; show itself.
It is at me he aims, the blood he drank
In&H4; Burgundie will&H1; not allay his thirst,
Orleance must administer a fresh supply:
But lest my wife and daughter whom I left
Slenderly guarded, fall into his hands,
(Which&H61; now is all the comfort I have left)
Come Gentlemen, I will&H1; dispatch your suit,
And afterwards ride post unto my house.
We&Htp; will&H1; attend upon&H4; your excellence.

div2.stage: Enter Barnabie Bunch a Botcher, with a paire of sheares, a handbasket with a crosse bottome of thred, three or foure paire of old stockings, peeces of fustian and cloath, &c

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Bonjour in&H4; French, is good morrow in&H4; English: true, and therewithal good morrow fair, what? maids? no&H7;, good morrow fair morning: and yet as fair as it looks I fear we&Htp; shall have rain, these French fleas bite so&H51; filthily. We&Htp; travellers are abject, that&H62; is to&H9; say, ordered to&H4; many mysteries and troubles: I Barnabie Bunch, the Botcher now, whilom (that&H62; is sometime) of a better trade: for&H3; I was an Ale-draper, as Thames and Tower wharf can witness: well, God be with them both: my honourable humour to&H9; learn language and see fashions, has lost me many a stout draught of strong Ale, what at London, what at Grauesend, where I was born. This Fraunce I confess is a goodly Country, but it breeds no&H2; Ale herbs, good water that&H62; is drink for&H4; a horse, and the vine blanket, and the vine Coverlet, that&H62; is vine Claret for&H4; great out-rich cobs. Well fare England, where the poor may have a pot of Ale for&H4; a penny, fresh Ale, firm Ale, nappy Ale, nippitate Ale, irregular, secular Ale, courageous, contagious Ale, alchemistical Ale. Well up&H5; with my ware, and down to&H4; my work, and on&H5; to&H4; my song, for&H3; a merry heart lives long.
sp.stage: He hangs three or foure paire of hose vpon a flicke, and falls to sowing one hose heele and sings.
sp.l: King Richards gone to&H4; Walsingham,
Kate is my goose roasted?
To&H4; the holy land.

l.hi: I mean my pressing Iron wench.
To&H9; kill Turk and Saracen that&H61; the truth do withstand.
Prithee make it hot, I must use it.
Christ his cross be his good speed, Christ his foes to&H9; quell,
Let it not be red hot Kate.
Send him help in&H4; time of need and to&H9; come home well.

sp.p: O for&H4; one pot of mother Bunches Ale, my own mothers Ale to&H9; wash my throat this misty morning: it would clear my sight, comfort my heart, and stuff my veins, that&H3; I should not smell the savour of these stockings: well fare cleanly. English men yet: these French men's fear have a pocky strong scent.
sp.stage: Enter two or three Citizens, one after an other, with Bags and Plate, and things to hide.
sp.l: Who&H62; be these that&H61; run so&H51; fearefully? ha? Citizens by&H4; the mass, Citizens, that&H61; look as they were scared.
Iohn Dorrie bought him an ambling Nag to&H4; Paris for&H3; to&H9; ride a,

l.hi: And happy ere they can seek and find, for&H3; they are gone to&H9; hide a.

sp.l: How blessed is this Botcher that&H61; can sing?
When all the City is set on&H4; sorrowing.
sp.stage: He seekes vp and downe for a place to hide his Plate.
sp.l: Where shall I hide this little that&H61; I have,
Whilst speedy flight attempt my life to&H9; save?
O unexpected sudden misery,
More bitter made by&H4; our&Htp; security:
We&Htp; unprovided, and our&Htp; foes at hand,
The head depressed how can the body stand?
Seek.
Where shall I shroud unseen this little pelf,
Whilst I by&H4; flight assay to&H9; save myself.
Whom have we&Htp; here? my gold will&H1; me betray.
Thee must I leave, with life to&H9; steal away.
Thou art my life, then if I live it is wonder,
When limbs and life are forced to&H9; part in&H4; sunder.
Who&H62; is there?
A friend: who&H62; thou?
No&H2; enemy, what is he?
A Citizen your neighbour, what fellow is that&H62;?
A Botcher, a poor English mechanic.
What shall we&Htp; do in&H4; this calamity?
Hide what we&Htp; have, and fly from the enemy.
O how near is he?
he will&H1; be here tonight.
No&H2; mean to&H9; save our&Htp; lives but present flight.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: What are these thick skinned heavy pursed gor-bellied churls mad? what do they fear? to&H9; be robbed I think: O that&H3; they would hide their money where I might find it, that&H62; should be the first language I would learn to&H9; speak: though I have no&H2; money, I am as merry as they, and well fare nothing once a year; For&H3; early up&H5; and never the near.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O whither fly ye silly heartless shadows?
What sudden fear so&H51; daunts your courages?
Are ye surprised with dread of enemies?
Then arm yourselves to&H9; guard yourselves and yours:
Let not base rumours drive ye from your den,
As Hares from forms; stay, fight, and die like&H4; men.
Noble Duke Lodwick, what avails our&Htp; stay,
When all our&Htp; power cannot defend one part?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: We&Htp; shall have help.
From whom?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: From Count Lauall.
No&H7; he and Trosthey are with Mercurie.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yet Monsieur Rossibroune may come in&H4; time.
All is but hazard, we&Htp; are sure of none.
Therefore God buy you my Lord, for&H3; I will&H1; save one.
And I another.
And I if I can.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Are ye all gone? stays there not one man?
Good fellow what art thou?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: A corrector of extravagant hose feet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Wilt thou abide?
And fight against the approaching enemy?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Envy? what envy?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The perjured Duke of Aniou, Mercurie,
That&H61; comes to&H9; sack this unprovided Town.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Is he near hand?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Aye, nearer than I wish.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: O that&H3; I had my pressing Iron out of the fire, and my clean shirt from my Laundress, that&H3; I might bid this town farewell, and bless it with my heels toward it: fie, fie, down with my stall, up&H5; with my wares, shift for&H4; myself.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: So&H3; all will&H1; leave me in&H4; extremity.

sp.speaker: Nuntio.
sp.l: Dear honoured Lord, make haste to&H9; save yourself.
The armed troupes of treacherous Mercury,
Approach so&H51; fast, and in&H4; such multitudes,
That&H3; some of them are seen within a league,
And not a man of ours&Htp; in&H4; readiness,
Except it be to&H9; run, none to&H9; resist.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then must I run as fast as they.
Lodwick till now was never runaway.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: If everybody run, its time for&H4; me to&H9; go: O that&H3; my customers had their ware, and I money for&H4; mending them, here is sudden wars when we&Htp; never thought upon&H4; it. Well, if I had had grace, I might have tarried at Tower wharf, armed with a white apron, a pot in&H4; my left hand, a chalk in&H4; my right: what makes this in&H4; the pie? six pence said I: fill here hey in&H4; the swan, by&H5; and by&H5;, anon, anon: there might I have eat my fill, and drunk my fill, and slept my fill, and all without fear, safe as mouse in&H4; a mill: here if the envy come, will&H1; be nothing, but kill, kill, kill: and I am sure to&H9; be in&H4; most danger, because I am an English man and a stranger, this is the luck of them that&H61; travel foreign lands: now one pair of running legs, are worth two pair of working hands.

div2.stage: Enter Duke Mercury with Souldiers>, Drumme, and Ensigne.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A plague upon&H4; you, was the Palace watched
That&H3; he and his have all escaped thus?
O I could tear my very heart strings out,
I am so&H51; stung with this indignity.
Will&H1; no&H2; man bring me word that&H3; he is taken?
Night wert thou anything, but what thou art,
A thick dark shadow, that&H61; art only seen,
I would not live, till thou wert banished,
But let him go, and now shall Aniou shine
More brighter than the burning lamp of heaven:
Wherein the height of the celestial signs,
In&H4; all his pomp he sails along the skies,
Now France shall shake with terror of my name,
Only my word shall be a Parliament,
Enacting statutes as shall bind the world,
Where majesty shall plead prerogative,
In&H4; mighty volumes writing with his hand,
The uncontrolled decrees of sovereignty:
Lodwick expulsed, and King Francis gone,
Yet once is Aniou King of Fraunce alone.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is Lodwick taken? ransom him to&H4; me,
And take my Dukedom whatsoever thou be.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: I am a Messenger of other news.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O but salute mine ears with that&H62; sweet sound,
And in&H4; that&H62; music be all accents drowned.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: My Lord: to&H4; Arms, to&H4; Arms, my Lord of Aniou,
The power of Spain hath past the Pyren hills,
And are already entered into France,
Under Hernando, the great Duke of Medena:
The Frontiers lie all blazed with rude war:
The fields are covered with uncivil arms
Of sun burnt Moors, and tawny Africans
Which&H61; they have brought: they scorn to&H9; bear their spoils
Their neighing Jennets, armed to&H4; the field
Do york and fling, and beat the sullen ground,
And uncontrolled, come loose abroad in&H4; France.
Nauarre is sacked, and like&H4; a mighty flood
The haughty Spaniard overturneth all.
Gather your power, make head against the foe:
The devil drives, it is full time to&H9; go.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The devil burst those balling chops of thine.
Spain and the plague, and hell and all together,
If the full tun of vengeance be abroach,
Fill out and swill until you burst again.
Come dog, come devil, he that&H61; scapes best.
Let him take all, and split, and rote, and choke
Hook, swords and caps, if hold will&H1; have it thus do
Let him lives longest, wipe the reckoning out,
Sound drum away, before our&Htp; glory die,
Some shall be low, that&H61; now do look full hie.

div2.stage: Enter Yacob van Smelt, Lodwick, Oriana, Dyan, and Bunch.

p.foreign: Well my life kins so ick must be you Wert, dat is you host; and you mine ghesse, to eat met mie, and slope met mie, in my huyo: well, here bene van you, vier, (foule as you seg in English) twea mannikins, twea tannikins, twea mans, twea womans: spreak, wat will you geuen by de dagh? by de weeke? by de mont? by de yeare? all to mall.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Saving your tale mine host, what is your name?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Smelt? Lord, many of your name are taken in&H4; the Thames, you will&H1; not be angry?

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Angry? niet niet.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: How? nit? nay then I perceive I shall be angry first: s'wounds twit me with my trade? I am the fag end of a Tailor; in&H4; plain English a Botcher: and though my country men do call me pricklouse, yet you Flemish Boor shall not call me nit; ye base Butter-box, ye Smelt, your kinsfolk dwell in&H4; the Thames and are sold like&H4; slaves in&H4; Cheap-side by&H4; the hundredth, two pence a quartern.

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Gods pestilence, beest thou frantic?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Patience my friends, fellow he spake no&H2; ill,
My gentle host was casting his account,
To&H4; what our&Htp; weekly charges must amount.

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Yaw, yaw, true, true.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: True, true? lie, lie: did not you say first you would mall us&Htp; all? and then called me nit, nit? it is not your big belly, nor your fat bacon, can carry it away, if ye offer us&Htp; the boots: what though we&Htp; be driven from our&Htp; own dwelling, there is more fitting houses than yours to&H9; host in&H5;.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well mine host Hiccup, though our&Htp; state be poor,
Yet will&H1; we&Htp; pay you justly our&Htp; compound:
For&H4; me, my wife, and daughter, by&H4; the week,
For&H4; diet, lodging, and for&H4; laundry,
So&H51; long as we&Htp; shall host within your house,
Five Guilders weekly I will&H1; answer you.

l.foreign: Dat is for you, your frow, and your skone daughter, well, whe a sall be tall for dis gack? dis shellam?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Aye, ye shall find me a tall fellow if ye try me. But what is it ye talk of me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He doth demand who&H62; shall defray thy charge?
For&H4; meat, and drink, and lodging in&H4; his house.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Neither you nor he, let him take care for&H4; a large winding sheet to&H9; wrap his fat guts in&H5;: have not I a trade? Yes good man Smelt, if ye have any hose to&H9; heel, breeches to&H9; mend, or buttons to&H9; set on&H5;, let me have your work.

l.foreign: Goots moorkne beest thou a Snyder? snip, snap, met te sheares.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Speak reverently of Tailors, or I will&H1; have ye by&H4; the ears.

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Yaw, yaw, it is good honest man's occupation, good true man's living.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Aye sir, I will&H1; live by&H4; it, and neither charge this man's purse, nor run upon&H4; your score, I will&H1; get me a little hole to&H9; put

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: A knaves head in&H5;.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: My head in&H5;, and fall to&H9; work here, and instead of parle buon francoys, learn to&H9; brawl out butter-box, yaw, yaw, and yawn for&H4; bear like&H4; a Jack daw.

l.foreign: Heare me eance Ick heb a cleyue skuttell, a litle stall by mine huys dore, sall dat hebben for a skoppe.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Hebben, habben quoth he? what shall I hebben?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A place to&H9; work in&H5; Yacob offers thee,
Hark hither Bunch.

div2.stage: He takes him aside and whispers.

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Aye Frau, hey, come here:
sp.stage: He takes Oriana by the hand.

l.foreign: You bene a skone Frow, a soot a lieffe: vp miner zeele, dat is, by my soule Ick loue you met my heart. And you will loue mee, smouch mee, and bee my secret vriend, de charle sall niet knowe, Ick will you gelt geuen, and you man sall niet betall, niet paid for your logies noe you meat: wat seg you?

sp.l: Oriana.
I say mine Host, that&H3; you are ill advised,
To&H9; tempt the honour of a stranger's wife:
Consider if your fortune were as ours&Htp;,
In&H4; foreign place to&H9; rest ye for&H4; a time,
Would you your wife should be allured to&H9; sin?
To&H9; break her&H2; vow and to&H9; dishonour you?

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Swig, swig, peace, Ick sall an aunder time talk with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No&H7; Bunch, by&H4; no&H2; means tell from whence we&Htp; came,
Nor what enforced us&Htp; seek a refuge here:
And though my want at instant be extreme,
Yet when the heavens shall better my estate,
Thy secrecy will&H1; I remunerate.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Why what do ye think of me? a horse-leach to&H9; suck ye? or a trencher fly to&H9; blow ye? or a vermin to&H9; spoil ye? or a moth to&H9; eat through ye? no&H7;, I am Barnabie Bunch, the Botcher, that&H61; never spent any man's goods but my own, I will&H1; labour for&H4; my meat, work hard, fare hard, lie hard, for&H4; a living, I will&H1; not charge ye a penny, I will&H1; keep your counsel. And ye shall command me to&H9; serve you, your wife, and your daughter in&H4; the way of honesty, like&H4; honest Barnabie.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Gramercies honest friend.
Oriana.
No&H7; Hiccup no&H7;,
Need cannot force, nor flattery entreat.

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Swig dan, nea meare, come shall us&Htp; in&H5; to&H9; eat?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Even when you please mine host: come daughter
Come, be of good comfort, heaven is where it was:
When fortunes storm a while our&Htp; state hath tossed,
A calmer gale may give what we&Htp; have lost.

sp.speaker: Dyana.
sp.l: Assure ye sir, even as I am your child,
Not discontent, but patience makes me mild,
If inward grief external joy supplant,
It moans not mine, but your unwonted want.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thou seest how easily I endure the smart,
Because thy mother and thyself bear part:
Come let us&Htp; in&H5;, on&H4; him that&H61; knows us&Htp; best
Let us&Htp; fix our&Htp; hope, and so&H3; in&H4; patience rest.

div2.stage: Enter Hernando de Medyna, and Don Vgo de Cordoua, with their souldiers.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It seems that&H3; the Nobility of Fraunce
Are all asleep, that&H3; unresisted, thus
We&Htp; dive into the entrails of their Land:
Is there no&H2; haughty chevalier, no&H2; spirit
Heroic, dare so&H51; much as once demand
Wherefore we&Htp; come? or offer us&Htp; the fight?
Why then proceed we&Htp; as we&Htp; have begun
To&H9; take possession, not to&H9; conquer here:
What City call you this?

sp.speaker: Vgo.
sp.l: Shamount my Lord.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Mount? whither does it mount? I will&H1; make it lie
As level as her&H2; other fellows do,
And though her&H2; lofty turrets touch the clouds,
Yet will&H1; I teach her&H6; like&H4; an humble handmaid,
To&H9; make a lowly curtsy to&H4; the ground:
Shamount shall stoop, Medyna says the word.
But who&H62; are these? Don Vgo question them.

sp.speaker: Vgo.
sp.l: Of whence are you? speak quickly, lest my sword
Prevent your tongues by&H4; searching of your hearts.
Great Prince of Spain, we&Htp; are the inhabitants
Of this distressed City of Shamount.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Yet more of Mount? shall I be haunted still
With echo of Shamount? how dare you slaves
Have any such proud title in&H4; your mouths?
Shall stoop I say, be that&H62; your Cities name,
For&H3; I will&H1; make it stoop before I pass.
Thou dread Commander of the Spanish Force,
If not for&H4; our&Htp; humility and prayers,
Yet for&H4; these presents which&H61; we&Htp; bring to&H4; thee,
(A Cup of gold, and in&H4; the same contained,
Five thousand Marks) respect our&Htp; naked walls,
Draw not thy sword against our&Htp; yielding souls,
But passing by&H5; in&H4; peace, let this alone,
(This harmless City amongst all other ruins)
Stand as a Trophy of thy clemency.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Would you corrupt our&Htp; valour with your coin?
Or do you think the Spaniard is so&H51; poor,
A little Gold can make him sell his honour?
No&H7;, were your streets through stoned with Diamonds,
And you should dig them up&H5; to&H9; bring them hither:
Or were your houses in&H4; the stead of Slate,
Covered with Silver, and yourselves prepared
To&H9; tear it off and give it us&Htp;,
Nay were your walls of purest Chrysolite,
And pulled beside their bounds for&H4; our&Htp; own use,
Yet would we&Htp; scorn all this and ten times more,
For&H3; we&Htp; count honour sweetness of dominion,
It is Lordship that&H3; we&Htp; come for&H5;, and to&H9; rule,
More worth than millions, stoop and kiss our&Htp; feet,
Bring forth your daughters and your fairest wives
To&H9; be our&Htp; Concubines, weight you yourselves
Upon&H4; our&Htp; trenchers, and like&H4; stable grooms,
Rub our&Htp; horse heels, and then perhaps we&Htp; will&H1; yield
That&H3; you shall live, or so&H52;, but otherwise,
Look for&H4; no&H2; pity at Medina's hand:
And for&H4; an instance, thus and thus I seal
The covenant of my great comptrolling sprite,
And now amain give onset to&H4; the town.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: First insolent Medyna, here is one
Will&H1; try how thou canst but end a man,
Before thou lay thy force unto a wall.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Now by&H4; mine honour welcome to&H4; the field,
Lives there a French man then dare try with us&Htp;?
I thought you had been Pygmies all till now,
And durst not look a Spaniard in&H4; the face,
But now I see you are of taller shapes,
However hearted that&H62; is yet unknown.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: So&H51; hearted Spaniard, as we&Htp; are resolved
To&H9; plague thee for&H4; thy damned cruelty.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Talk then no&H2; longer, show your Chivalry.

div2.stage: Alarum, they fight, Mercurie is wounded, and put to flight.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Was this the worthy champion so&H52; resolved,
To&H9; plague us&Htp; as he said? was this the man
Fraunce had picked out, to&H9; take her&H2; quarrel up&H5;?
Now sure a trusty wight, when hands serve not,
He knows the way to&H9; take him to&H4; his heels:
Yet is it good that&H3; we&Htp; did meet with him
Be it but for&H4; this, to&H9; keep our&Htp; hands in&H4; ure,
And breath our&Htp; pursy bodies, which&H61; I fear,
Would have grown stiff for&H4; want of exercise.
But now no&H2; more, enter the City gates,
And therein boldly everyone devise,
How he can Lord it in&H4; the French men's eyes.

sp.speaker: Ema.
sp.l: Could I resolve myself sufficiently,
He should not stay one hour in&H4; my Court,
But I have noted in&H4; her&H6; from her&H2; birth,
A strange innated kind of courtesy,
An affable, inclining lenity,
With such a virgin meekness to&H9; regard,
As may abuse, a wise and grounded censure,
In&H4; judging of affection, and of honour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Pardon me gracious Lord, I speak it not
In&H4; any sort to&H9; wrong your Princely daughter,
Or to&H9; impeach your judgment any wise
In&H4; your opinion of the Gentleman,
But as a just and honest subject should,
In&H4; matters that&H61; concern my trust so&H51; much.

sp.speaker: Ema.
sp.l: Nor as I am a Prince I think thou dost,
I have so&H51; good assurance of thy love,
Which&H61; may I trust, induce thee to&H9; resolve me,
From what conceit proceeds thy strong surmise.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This other day, for&H4; hunting of the stag,
Attending fair Odillia to&H4; the Forest,
When as the hounds had roused the trembling deer,
And every man spurred hard unto the cry,
Riding along, a goodly Covert side:
The company all straggling here and there,
Only the Princess, and young Ferdynand,
Curbing their steeds in&H5; with their silken reins,
Into a Grove road secretly together,
Thrice did I see him kiss her&H2; snowy hand,
And with three humble Curtsies bowed his head,
Down to&H4; the stirrup of Odillia,
Then did I see him whisper in&H4; her&H2; ear,
When with her&H2; Fan she won the wanton wind
To&H9; cool his face as they rode gently on&H5;.
Then came they to&H4; a little pearling Brooke,
Whereas they paused, as it should seem to&H9; hear
The birds sweet music, to&H4; the bubbling stream.
Then did I see him lift his eyes towards hers,
Taking her&H2; glove which&H61; lay upon&H4; her&H2; lap,
A thousand times did reverence to&H4; the same,
And in&H4; his Baldrick wrapped it choicely up&H5;,
When as she plucked a bloomed Lemon branch,
With her&H2; white hand out of her&H2; Coronet,
And with her&H2; fingers twinned it in&H4; his lock
And smiled: and bowed her&H2; head into his bosom.
And thus with gentle parlance both together
They paced on&H5; unto the flowery lawn.

sp.speaker: Ema.
sp.l: If this be not surmised which&H61; thou reportest,
It should be sign of some affection.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will&H1; not enforce it on&H4; your excellence
By&H4; circumstance: but only this I saw.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Where is Ferdynando? saw you him of late?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Lord Strossy, and your daughter be at chests,
And they saw him, but even very now.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Go call them hither presently to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I trust you will&H1; not urge me in&H4; the matter.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Go to&H5;, I will&H1; not.
How now? a villain that&H61; I found by&H4; chance,
To&H9; court my only daughter and my heir:
And having thus revived him by&H4; my favours,
Will&H1; the vile viper sting me for&H4; my love?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Sirrah come hither, didst thou never hear
How first I found thee, being but a child:
Hid in&H4; the sedges fast by&H4; a River side,
As it should seem of purpose to&H9; be lost.
Being so&H51; young, that&H3; thou hadst not the sense
To&H9; tell thy name, or of what place thou wast?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I have heard your Lordship often so&H52; report it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Did thy adulterous parents cast thee off
As it should seem, ashamed of thy birth?
And have I made a nursery of my Court
To&H9; foster thee, and grown to&H4; what thou art,
Enrich thee with my favours everywhere?
That&H61; from the loathsome mud from whence thou camest,
Thou art so&H51; bold out of thy buzzards nest,
To&H9; gaze upon&H4; the sun of her&H2; perfections?
Is there no&H2; beauty that&H61; can please your eye,
But the divine and splendent excellence
Of my beloved dear Odillia?
How darest thou but with trembling and with fear
Look up&H5; toward the heaven of her&H2; hie grace?
And even astonished with the admiration,
Let fall the gaudy plumes of thy proud heart?
Dare any wretch so&H51; vile and so&H51; obscure,
Attempt the honour of so&H51; great a Princess?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Hear me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Odillia.
sp.l: Nay hear me Princely father,
For&H3; what you speak to&H4; him concerns me most.
Never did he attempt to&H9; wrong mine honour,
Nor did his tongue ere utter yet one accent,
But what a virgins ear might safely hear.
I never saw him exercise himself
In&H4; any place where I myself was present,
But with such a graceful modest bashfulness,
As well beseemed both his youth and duty.
I never saw him yet presume my presence
But with a low subjected reverence,
A brow as humble as humility:
And when I have enforced him to&H9; speak,
In&H4; anything I had employed him in&H5;,
His words have been in&H4; such an humble key,
As silence would have told a secret in&H5;.
But if his service to&H4; me be suspected,
Attending me to&H9; help me to&H4; my horse,
Or bent my bow when I have shot a Deer,
Discourse of Nations, played at Maw and Chess:
Or led me by&H4; the arm when I had walked.
If this may breed suspicion of my love,
I cannot keep the tongue of jealousy.

sp.speaker: Frede.
sp.l: When did I ever but approach the place
Where she hath been, but kneeling to&H4; the earth
As if the ground were holy where she trod?
When was I seen to&H9; gaze once in&H4; her&H2; glass,
For&H4; fear the Crystal wherein she beheld her&H6;,
Should tell my disobedience to&H4; her&H2; eyes?
When was I seen to&H9; smell but to&H4; a flower
To&H4; which&H61; the Princess had but smelt before
As far unworthy that&H3; my sense should taste
So&H51; rich an odour as had pleased hers?
When was I seen to&H9; look once in&H4; her&H2; face,
But as a man beholding of the sun,
That&H61; cast his head down dazzled with his rays.
I never named that&H62; name, Odillia:
But with such worship, and such reverence,
As to&H4; an Angel if he should appear.
Her&H6; have I loved for&H4; fear, and feared for&H4; love,
For&H3; I adore divine Odillia.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Frederick, thy humble and submissive carriage,
Hath satisfied me fully at this time.
And my Odillia, take it not in&H4; ill part,
That&H3; too much love breaks out into suspicion,
It is the fault of love Odillia,
And hath his pardon as it doth offend:
Then come Leontius, you and I will&H1; away,
Go back Odillia, and attend your play.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Madam you see, that&H3; jealousy attends
Upon&H4; the hours of our&Htp; successful love,
What is your princely pleasure with my service?
I fear suspicion but too much espies,
I see that&H3; trees had ears, and bushes eyes.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Dear Ferdynand, provide then for&H4; our&Htp; flight,
I regard nothing in&H4; respect of thee,
Only be constant, and I will&H1; go with thee,
In&H4; all the ways that&H61; fortune can direct.
Go get you hence, I will&H1; attend my sport,
Much is to&H9; do, and time is very short.

div2.stage: Enter Yacob, and Lodwick, Yacob hath a long boord chalked.

p.foreign: Come, floux, betall, gelt Lodwick, gelt, ware bene de Fraunce Crowne? de Riex daler? de Anglis skelling? ha? pay pay, betall betall, keck dore Lodwick, see de creete de chalke: eane, twea, dree, vier guildern for brant weene: fiftick guildern for rost for de eat zeuen guildern for speck, case, bouter and bankeate: keck, looke in dye burse betall shellam betall, Ick mought gelt heb come, pay.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My gentle host have patience but a while,
I will&H1; endeavour to&H9; come out of debt,
As speedily as God shall give me means,
Forbearing neither lessons nor acquits
One groat of duty, only your good mind
Shall be approved for&H4; respiting a time.
Yacob.

p.foreign: Respit? rest diuell, godts cruse, my gelt 'ck can niet forbeare, niet suffer, niet spare mine gelt, a dowsand diuells, Ick mought de Brewer, de Baker, de Butcher betall, so heb ye niet gelt, giue me a pawne, eane gage: oh haere dat his Frow mought met my blieuen for de debt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yacob, alas thou seest what wealth I have,
Apparel, Jewels, Plate, and Gold I lack,
Fortune hath wracked me on&H4; extremity,
For&H3; all my riches are within thy house.
My virtuous wife and daughter are my treasure,
Which&H61; above all worlds wealth beside I measure.
Yacob.

p.foreign: Godts Sacrament harma charle begger, a wench, loupe dye selue, ye sall niet slape eane nought mare in mine huys, geue me dy Frow and dye Meskyn, wyeffe and doughter to pledge for my gelt, for Ick weat well, dow wilt redeeme and raunsome dem twea: loupe doo shellam and nempt de gelt and coine, here and buy out dy wife and kinde, dy skone daughter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Alas what comfort is there left for&H4; me
If those dear Jewels be impawned to&H4; thee?
My wife and daughter? Hiccup change thy mind,
Divide us&Htp; not, O be not so&H51; unkind.
Yacob.

p.foreign: Godts hanny kin, vnkind? But Boore geue mee gelt or pawne, or Ick sall dee in de vanga port staruen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No&H2; remedy? well, call my wife and daughter,
If they consent to&H9; be engaged to&H4; thee,
I will&H1; leave them, else, thou shalt imprison me.

p.foreign: Ha, godks tostie mought Icke de skone Frow his wieff here hold, Ick begare niet cost, niet ziluer niet gold.
Dore she comen, dore, dore, all so clare, wyet and zoole, as de zunne, wellicome zoota lieff, hey couragee mine wan, alls ge done.

sp.speaker: Oriana.
sp.l: What Planets opposition have we&Htp; here,
That&H61; makes a storm in&H4; sunshine, heat in&H4; frost?
The heavens are clouded, drossy earth is clear,
My husband frowns, but frolic is mine host,
O fire and Ice, O fear and doubt together,
What envious star directs my coming hither?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No&H2; heavier star nor more malevolent
Needs Lodwick, than this Flemish excrement.
Dear Oriana, thou dost know our&Htp; state
Cast down, spurned, scorned by&H4; fortune, and by&H4; fate,
Yet never grief so&H51; nearly galls my heart,
As when I think that&H3; thou and I must part.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Why must we&Htp; part?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ask Hiccup, he can tell.

p.foreign: Well meyster, well yffrow, Ick mought de gelt heb, ye man hebt niet to betall, he sall niet langer in my huys blieuen, keck see dore de skore Ick will him trust nea mare Ick mought eane gage, eane pawnd heb dat must you selua bene, and you skone daughter by godth moorky he fall to prison to de vanga port els.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, then I must persuade her&H2; patience,
To&H9; be thy pawn, thy prisoner in&H4; mine absence.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: What? how pawn? how prisoner? for&H4; what? for&H4; the score? a pox on&H4; that&H62; chalk, its an easier matter to&H9; chalk a pound, then to&H9; get a penny to&H9; pay it: you shall not go, nor she shall not lie to&H9; gage for&H4; a little money: let me see how much it is? what be these Guilderns?

div2.stage: Lodwick whispers with Oriana and Dyana.

l.foreign: Yaw eleck eane a Guilder.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Fifty, and four, and seven, is five and forty, mass I have but twenty Stivers toward it, that&H61; all I have saved since I came here to&H4; Newkerk. This Flanders is too thrifty a country, for&H3; here the women will&H1; heel their husbands hose themselves: faith if your score had been but a score of Stivers, I mean I would have paid it, cleared the chalk clean.

p.foreign: Swegen and drinkin Bunch, de skone Frow and se daughter sall be mien pawne, mien gage, me de Frow, dow de Meskyn.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Ha, say you so&H52;? no&H7; Butter-box, I will&H1; set a spoke in&H4; your cart: hear ye? this soul fat Smelt, tells me, that&H3; he has smelt out a smock commodity for&H4; a pawn, that&H61; is to&H9; have your wife and daughter to&H9; gage: if ye be wise, make your bargain that&H3; he do not use your pawn, for&H3; though it will&H1; not be much the worse for&H4; the wearing, yet it is pity it should be slubbered by&H4; such a cullion as Yacob Smelt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Prithee be quiet, Yacob I will&H1; leave
My dearest, most unvalued Jewels here:
Entreat them well as thou wilt answer me
At my return, even with thy dearest blood,
If they miscarry in&H4; thy custody.
Friend Bunch farewell, be kind unto these twain,
And if I live I will&H1; recompense thy pain.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Faith as kind as Cockburne, I will&H1; break my heart to&H9; do them good. But whither will&H1; you go?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know not yet, where fortune shall direct,
Leave us&Htp; a while to&H9; take a sad farewell:
That&H62; done, I part, and they shall stay with you.

p.foreign: Wel, wel, hah mien skone friester, mien lieff, dow sall met mie blieuen, and di mannykin a weigh lope, heigh loustick.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Gep, wihi, see how the slovenly Smelt leaps: I think you could be content to&H9; be rid of this beer fly, this bacon faced Butter-box a while.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Indeed I could.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Indeed and you shall, Yacob I have news for&H4; ye, passing profitable pleasurable news: there is a tun of English stark beer, new come to&H4; Newkerk this day, at two Stivers a stope, come I will&H1; give thee a stope or two.

l.foreign: Gramercies Bunch, braue Bunch, mien lieuer brooer, Anglis beere? oh heare tosti godts towsand a weigh gane?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
Lod.
sp.l: Ah beastly brutal, baser than the dung,
That&H61; hast no&H2; touch nor feeling of my want,
That&H3; such a drunken greasy slave discards:
Ah Oriana, never till this hour
Did I confess my want or misery,
For&H3; but of thee, and my poor sweet Dyana,
I never made account that&H3; aught was mine,
But poorer now than poverty itself,
Of all I had you only were the best,
Now must I too, forgo you with the rest.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Ah must we&Htp; part? why whither wilt thou go?
Ah my dear Lord, yet whilst we&Htp; lived together,
With what content have we&Htp; endured our&Htp; woe?
Now like&H4; a sea tossed Navy in&H4; a storm,
Must we&Htp; be severed unto divers shores?
O that&H3; the poorest beggars that&H61; do breath
Should yet have that&H62; which&H61; is denied to&H4; us&Htp;,
But to&H9; have partners in&H4; their misery.

sp.speaker: Dya.
sp.l: Good father since our&Htp; fortune is to&H9; beg,
Let me become the beggar for&H4; you both:
What shall become of me, if you do leave me?
Many will&H1; give me bread if I do ask,
But there is none that&H61; can give me a father.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ah my poor wench, if I should stay with you,
This gripple miser, this uncivil wretch,
Will&H1; for&H4; this little that&H61; I am indebted,
Unchristianly imprison you and me,
Where we&Htp; shall surely perish then for&H4; want.
But I will&H1; cross the narrow seas for&H4; England
To&H4; London: where ere long I make no&H2; doubt,
To&H9; get so&H51; much, as shall redeem you hence,
And shall redeem this poor estate of ours&Htp;,
Till fairer fortune hap to&H9; show her&H2; head.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: Farewell, farewell: now all my joy doth go,
Go you alone, while we&Htp; alone with woe.

sp.speaker: Dya.
sp.l: Farewell dear father.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My sweet girl adiew,
He bless us&Htp; all, that&H61; keeps both me and you.

div2.stage: Exit Lodwick. Enter Yacob and Bunch to Oriana and Dyana.

p.foreign: Com't here Bunch, dow beest eane right shapt charle: O de stark Anglis beere; whore zijne, whoare zijne dieffrow and de skone daughter? keck dore Bunch, nempt de meskyn, Ick fall de moore hebben: come Oriana, ou beene miene gage vor gelt, mijen liuer loue, mijen zooterkyn.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Your sooterkin? your drunken skin, mistress how do ye? is your husband gone? why be of good cheer, here is a bunch of botchers left to&H9; comfort ye, take all in&H4; my purse, spend all that&H61; I get, and command my work to&H9; help ye out of debt.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Thanks gentle friend, but how shall I requite it?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Tush, talk not of quittance, I will&H1; live by&H4; a pittance, unline my purse, and use my person, and for&H4; my limbs take the best in&H4; the bunch.

p.foreign: Godts sacremente Bunch, sweg, sweg, come yffrow dye man is away gane, lat ource be frolicke, lustick, heigh speell zing and daunce. Ick loue mijne Lyuerkin heye, Ick basse mijne zoota lieffe ho: ick mot niet slape, niet drenk zane stopemedoont mijne Iolickaa froe, hey lustick.

sp.speaker: Dya.
sp.l: Wilt please ye mother, leave this barbarous beast,
And take you to&H4; your chamber?

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: Aye my child.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: I will&H1; tell thee Smelt, thou shouldst be a Codshead thou art so&H51; rude: I am of the house of the Bunches, a bunch of keys will&H1; jingle, a bunch of lathes will&H1; ring, a bunch of roots are windy meat, and a bunch of garlic will&H1; make ye sweat, yet I keep no&H2; stir.

l.foreign: Shellamick be gare niet dyffroes bene gan.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Then let us&Htp; follow, we&Htp; shall overtake them anon.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Imperious fortune when thou dost begin
To&H9; show thine anger, how implacable
And how remorseless are thy bitter checks?
To&H4; loss of honour, danger of my life:
To&H4; the endangering of my life, thou addest
A separation twixt my wife and me.
To&H4; that&H62;, base poverty: to&H4; that&H62;, contempt:
And now thou takest from me my strength of limbs,
Enfeebling me for&H4; lack of sustenance.
All this thou givest me of thine own accord,
One thing let me entreat thee to&H9; restore,
Which&H61; with my tears I beg, though thou wouldst send
Death, to&H9; fill up&H5; the measure of thy spite:
That&H3; it may be sufficient thou hast forced
My heart to&H9; sigh, my hands to&H9; beat my breast,
My feet to&H9; travel, and my eyes to&H9; weep,
Enjoin not now my tongue to&H9; ask an alms,
But thou art deaf, and I must either beg
Or starve for&H4; food to&H9; comfort me withal,
And lo in&H4; happy time here cometh one.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas reading very earnestly on a Letter.
sp.l: Where I may make a trial of my skill,
A man it seems belonging to&H4; the Church,
I have some knowledge in&H4; the Latin tongue,
Perhaps for&H4; that&H62; he will&H1; sooner pity me.

foreign.hi: Et occulos flecte tuos in miserum,

sp.speaker: Sir Ni.
sp.l: What is this?

sp.speaker: Sir Ni.
sp.l: It seems that&H3; thou art needy, and wouldst beg
An alms of me, is that&H62; thy meaning, speak?

l.foreign: Ita domine ita, nam vehementer.

sp.speaker: Sir Ni.
sp.l: Tut a figs end, vehementer quoth he?
There is a word indeed to&H9; beg withal:
It is enough to&H9; bring thee to&H4; the stocks.
This is no&H2; University, nor School,
But a poor Village: and I promise thee,
I never could abide this Romish tongue.
It is harsh, it is harsh, and we&Htp;, I tell thee true,
Do eat and drink in&H4; our&Htp; plain mother phrase:
If thou dost want, and wouldst have part with us&Htp;,
Then do as we&Htp; do, like&H4; an honest man,
Show thy true meaning in&H4; familiar terms.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am good sir, if please you, much distressed,
Having nor money, friends, nor meat to&H9; eat:
If it may stand with your humanity
To&H9; give me some relief, I will&H1; pray for&H4; you,
And whilst I live be thankful for&H4; the same.

sp.speaker: S. Ni.
sp.l: Why so&H52;, now I understand thy meaning,
Is not this better far than respice
And precor, and such Inkhorn terms,
As are intolerable in&H4; a Common-wealth?
Conjurers do use them, and thou knowest
That&H3; they are held flat Felons by&H4; the law.
Be sure thou mightst have begged till thou were hoarse,
And talked until thy tongue had had the cramp,
Before thou wouldst have been regarded once.
It is not good to&H9; be fantastical,
Or scrupulous in&H4; such a case as this.
But to&H4; the purpose, thou art poor thou sayst?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Exceeding poor, poorer than Irus,
He did enjoy the quiet of the mind,
Although his body were exposed to&H4; want:
But I in&H4; body and in&H4; mind am vexed.

sp.speaker: S. Ni.
sp.l: I fear by&H4; keeping riotous company
Or some such misdemeanour?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then I wish,
That&H3; God may turn your heart from pitying me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ni.
sp.l: Well, thou sayst well, thou hast an honest face,
And art beside, a pretty handsome fellow:
Methinks thou couldst not want a service long,
If thou wouldst be contented to&H9; take pains.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O sir, the world is grown so&H51; full of doubts,
Or rather so&H51; confounded with self-love,
As if a poor man beg, they straight condemn him,
And say, he is an idle vagabond:
Or if he ask a service, or to&H9; work,
They straightaway are suspicious of his truth:
So&H3; that&H3; however, they will&H1; find excuse,
That&H3; he shall still continue miserable.
And it is as common as it is true withal,
The weakest ever go unto the wall.

sp.speaker: Sir Ni.
sp.l: By&H4; my faith thou sayst true, the more is the pity.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But if you will&H1; vouchsafe, because my state
Is very bare, and I am here unknown,
To&H9; be a means to&H9; help me to&H4; some place,
Where I may serve: my pains I do not doubt,
Shall prove my poverty no&H2; counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Sir Ni.
sp.l: Faith I must tell thee, I have little coin,
My Benefice doth bring me in&H5; no&H2; more
But what will&H1; hold bare buckle and thong together,
And now and then to&H9; play a game at bowls:
Or drink a pot of Ale amongst good fellows.
And for&H4; my Parishioners, they are husbandmen,
Nor do I know of any lacks a servant.
But this, the Sexton of our&Htp; Church is dead,
And we&Htp; do lack an honest painful man,
Can make a grave, and keep our&Htp; Clock in&H4; frame,
And now and then to&H9; toll a passing bell:
If thou art willing so&H52; to&H9; be employed,
I can befriend thee.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O withal my heart,
And think me treble happy by&H4; the office.

sp.speaker: Sir Ni.
sp.l: Thy wages is not great, not much above
Two Crowns a quarter, but thy vails will&H1; help,
As first the making of a grave is a groat,
Then ringing of the bell at every burial,
Two pence a knell: which&H61; likewise is a groat.
And now and then the masters of our&Htp; Parish,
(As good man Flaile, and Bartholmew Pitchfork)
Will&H1; bid thee home to&H9; dine and sup with them.
Beside, thou hast a house to&H9; dwell in&H5; rent-free:
And for&H4; the liking that&H61; I have in&H4; thee,
Thou shalt be somewhat better too for&H4; me:
The grazing of a pig within the Churchyard,
Or when I gather up&H5; my Tithes, an egg,
A good hogs pudding, or a piece of souse:
What man it is? good fare in&H4; a country house,
Come follow me, I will&H1; see thee placed forthwith.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I thank you sir, when all things run awry,
True labour must not be thought slavery.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: If you be able to&H9; endure the way
Till we&Htp; have passed Brabant, we&Htp; will&H1; on&H5;:
But Madam, if you hardly brooke your travel,
We&Htp; will&H1; take the right hand way into the Forest,
Where we&Htp; will&H1; shroud us&Htp; secretly till night.

sp.speaker: Odillia.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; not stay near to&H4; my fathers Court,
Not for&H4; a world I would not hazard thee,
No&H2; world could save if taken thou shouldst be,
Methinks it is long before the sun arise.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: A it is long Odillia of thine eyes,
Who&H61; slumbering still, imagines it is night,
And that&H3; the shining is his sisters light.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: No&H7;, it is the Moon, sweet Ferdynand I see,
Keeps back her&H2; brother still to&H9; look on&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I marvel not poor light if she decline,
When my Odillia doth so&H51; early shine.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Come, come, sweet love, O I am full of fear,
Be I the Moon, thine arm must be my sphere.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O were I heaven, thou ever shouldst shine there.

sp.speaker: Ema.
sp.l: O misery, why didst thou bait my fall
With these descending shadows of my good?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: My Lord, never stand upon&H4; these vain exclaims,
But by&H4; pursuit, seek to&H9; redress your wrongs,
It is speedy expedition must recover,
What light belief, and oversight hath lost.

sp.speaker: Ema.
sp.l: Horses I say, let horses be sent forth,
No&H2; Christian Prince that&H61; treads on&H4; Europe's mold,
I think that&H61; will&H1; so&H51; far engage his honour,
As entertain this damned fugitive.
Horses I say, spur, spur, through every coast,
Put on&H5; the wings of speedy expedition,
In&H4; the pursuit of my Odillia:
Deafen the very air with your exclaims,
And fill each Province with the ceaseless brute,
Ring out this famous wrong in&H4; your pursuit.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Come, come, my Lord, incessant speed must post,
Words cannot get what you have vainly lost.

l.foreign: Oh here godt, mijne lifekin, whare will ye from mee ganne?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Farewell mine host, we&Htp; are for&H4; England bound,
Out of your debt, for&H3; you are satisfied.

l.foreign: Yaw, yaw, ye heb well betalld.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: So&H3; leave I you to&H9; seek my husband out,
Whom your uncivil usage forced hence,
Your imperfections (Yacob) are extreme,
Excess in&H4; diet, kindled fire of lust,
The smoke whereof unkindly chased away
My loving husband, whom I must pursue.
We&Htp; owe ye nothing, not so&H51; much as love,
Since for&H4; your lust you have abused us&Htp; all,
We&Htp; have not fallen, though want did wrestle hard:
Our&Htp; fingers ends our&Htp; honours have sustained,
Flanders farewell, irksome without my Lord,
And Newkerke for&H4; his sake be thou abhorred.

sp.speaker: Ya.
sp.l: Hore ye well yffrow? ken ye whare to&H9; find your man?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I trust at London.

sp.speaker: Dya.
sp.l: Mother, please you go?
The air is infected where this glutton breathes,
That&H61; makes us&Htp; Pilgrims without devotion.
Amend thy manners, or let all refuse
To&H9; host with thee, that&H61; wouldst thy guess abuse.

div2.stage: Exit Orian, and Dyana: manet Yacob.

l.foreign: Adiew skone meskyn, adiew zoot frow,
Ick will mijne selue strauen vp de galligo bobbintow,
Ick sall be dode slone met dis meager loue.
Sweg Yacob sweg, here comt Bunch dat boue.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.l: Now mine Host rob pot, empty can, Beer sucker, Gudgeon, Smelt I should say, have the women paid ye?

sp.speaker: Yacob.
sp.l: Yaw, yaw, all to&H4; mall.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: All to&H4; mall, drunken Cannibal, and where be they I pray ye?

l.foreign: A Bunch, Bunch, deye bene aweigh lop't,
Deye will niet langer met mije blieuen.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Be living ye blockhead? no&H7;, thou art such a drunken Goat, that&H3; the devil will&H1; not dwell with thee, except he be in&H4; thy coat.
sp.l: And whither are they gone Beer Barrel?

sp.speaker: Ya.
sp.l: Ick weat not, for&H4; England, for&H4; Loundres they said.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.l: How? for&H4; England? for&H4; London?
O Saint Katherns Dock,
And leave me behind them?
Yacob dost thou not mock?

l.foreign: Niet for ware.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: For&H4; Ware drunkard? thou saidst for&H4; London even now.

sp.speaker: Ya.
sp.l: Yaw for&H4; Loundres, it is ware, it is true.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Then gentle Swill-bowl, I will&H1; bid Flanders adieu. O pitiless parcels of women's flesh, that&H61; knew London is my Country, and for&H4; all my good will&H0; would not call me to&H4; their Company: Well, Bunch will&H1; not ban them, nor yet follow them, nor yet tarry here: but take up&H5; my tools, my pressing Iron and Shears, my Needle and Thimble, and back again for&H4; Fraunce, to&H9; learn more oui, and oui daw, and so&H3; farewell Yacob with your great maw.
sp.l: Adieu mine host lick-spigot at the sign of the slipper,
When you meet with the Cat, for&H4; my sake whip her&H6;.

l.foreign: Ha Bunch, mijen hart is gebroke, ick mought niet lang leuen,
Come met mey rat parting, ick sall detwea stopes van Bere geuen.

sp.speaker: Ferdi.
sp.l: Thus far (sweet Lady) safely are we&Htp; scaped,
And hardly shall they overtake us&Htp; now,
Though every way pursuit do follow us&Htp;.
Be cheerful then Odillia, Love is guide
Who&H61; swears that&H3; Fortune shall us&Htp; not divide.

sp.speaker: Odillia.
sp.l: Dear Ferdinand I neither fear nor doubt,
Peril is but a Bugbear for&H4; a child,
My heart is firm, and fortified with love,
Witness this desperate tender of mine honour
Into thy hands, which&H61; thou hast yet preserved.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And will&H1; preserve it whilst I draw this breath,
And bring it sacred to&H4; our&Htp; nuptial bed.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Then Ferdinand belike ye mean to&H9; wed?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Mean not you so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Yes, but with whom?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam I trust with me.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Well mayst thou trust, I will&H1; marry none but thee.
I know thy bringing up&H5;, though not thy birth,
Thou art derived from Adam, formed of earth:
From that&H62; first Parent all descended are,
Then who&H61; begat or bare thee that&H62; is not my care.
Thou stolest my heart, I stole with thee thus far,
Love wrought our&Htp; joy, lack shall not make us&Htp; jar.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O happy accents of a heavenly tongue.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; journey on&H5;, we&Htp; tarry here too long.
Alas who&H62; is this?
Bunch.
Faith one that&H61; will&H1; do ye no&H2; wrong.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Peasant thou canst not.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.l: No&H7; sir ye are deceived, I am no&H2; Peasant, I am Bunch the Botcher: Peasants be ploughmen, I am an Artificial.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Simple and pleasant this poor fellow seems,
Question him further Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I will&H1;: My friend where are we&Htp;?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Cannot you tell?

sp.speaker: Ferdi.
sp.l: No&H7;.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Then ye have no&H2; wit, are not we&Htp; here I pray you?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We&Htp; are here indeed, but say what country is this?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Nay ye asked me not that&H62; before,
Nor I cannot tell ye it now.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Whither go you my friend?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: It is true indeed your friend, and Barnabie Bunch,
I am going to&H4; Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And can ye speak French?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Aye sir I would be sorry else.

l.foreign: D'ou veni vou?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: I never learned so&H51; far, I cannot tell ye that&H62;, I am but a stranger in&H4; the country: here comes one perchance can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I pray you sir what territory is this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Part of the base country of Fraunce it is,
The Village name is Ards in&H4; Picardy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What entertainment can the town afford
To&H4; travellers?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Too mean for&H4; such as you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Inhabit you this Village?

sp.speaker: Ld.
sp.l: Aye forsooth.
Why gazest thou upon&H4; me so&H52; my friend?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: By&H4; Jacob's staff and Jumball's fiddle,
Because I will&H1; expose ye with a Riddle.
Two hes, two shes, by&H4; night fled touch,
And light upon&H4; a hannykin Dutch.
Yacob builded a new kirk.
And with his chalk writ such a quirk,
That&H3; wife and child were left alone,
The score is paid, and they are gone.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Let this alone friend till an other time,
My skill is small in&H4; Riddles or in&H4; Rime,
Be silent Bunch, till we&Htp; be rid of these.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You seem a man belonging to&H4; the Church,
And we&Htp; have Church-work to&H9; be finished:
In&H4; plainest terms, we&Htp; would be married,
Accomplish our&Htp; desire for&H4; recompense.
Lod.
I blush not at my calling Gentleman,
The Sexton's place of Ards I now profess,
If that&H62; fair damsel do consent with you,
I will&H1; call the Vicar to&H9; conjoin ye straight.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Call him good friend, for&H3; my consent is past.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.l: Nay but call him quickly, for&H3; ye see she is in&H4; haste.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Master, Sir Nicholas, here is a commodity,
A marriage that&H61; must quickly be despatched.

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.l: Gramercy Sexton, this was fitly watched.
Welcome fresh Gallants to&H4; the Town of Ards.
A pretty couple, youthful as the spring, sweet as is May
morning, do you desire to&H9; be knit together?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: In&H4; holy marriage (Sir) would we&Htp; be joined.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: In&H4; holy wedlock Gentles, so&H3; I mean,
Ye are in&H4; the state of grace, Twins in&H4; affection,
Turtles in&H4; true love, I know ye have no&H2; License,
And it is no&H2; matter; holy matrimony shall pass my liberty
Without examining: you will&H1; pay me?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Come, I will&H1; glue ye together by&H5; and by&H5;,
To&H4; the lawful bed, to&H4; the lawful bed:
Fie on&H4; this Fornication, this lascivious lust:
And yet the flesh pricks my holy self now and then:
Come follow me, I will&H1; call some more witness,
And clap it up&H5; presently.

div2.stage: Ex. Ferdinand, Odillia, and Nicholas. Manent Lod. and Bunch, who haue whispered.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But are my wife and daughter gone indeed
For&H4; London? and have paid the debt we&Htp; ought?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: By&H4; my shears, (and that&H62; is a shaving oath)
They are gone for&H4; London, they have paid Yacob:
But they shall loose their labour,
Because you are not in&H4; England.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But I will&H1; send, or I will&H1; soon be there,
I must not live divided from my joy.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: And yet I think you live well
By&H4; this Science of Sextonship:
Lord, do not you pray that&H3; the pip may catch the people,
That&H3; you may gain many groats for&H4; making graves?
Your Church wardens find bell-ropes,
And you hands to&H9; shake them

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thou art a mad fellow; but how knewest thou me,
In&H4; this disguise?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Tut well enough; But hark the Vicar calls.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come Bunch, we&Htp; will&H1; find more time to&H9; talk anon:

div2.stage: Enter Hernandos Don Hugo and Mercury disguisde, in priuate conference with Hernando, with Souldiours.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I like&H1; thy words, and though I reck not much
The death of any private man in&H4; France,
Because in&H4; multitudes consists our&Htp; glory:
Yet to&H9; make known how we&Htp; do cherish such
As will&H1; in&H4; any sort revolt to&H4; us&Htp;,
Kill Epernoune as thou hast undertaken,
And thy reward shall be a Tun of gold.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hernando I will&H1; do it, not so&H51; much
For&H4; money, as for&H4; zeal I bear to&H4; Spain,
Though I confess the principal reason
That&H61; urgeth me being a French man born,
So&H52; to&H9; forget the love my Country claims,
Is the unsufferable wrongs I bear,
The wrongs that&H61; Epernoune hath done to&H4; me,
And in&H4; that&H62; point I hold it no&H2; disgrace
To&H9; malice him, that&H61; first dishonoured me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Why true, thy reason is substantial.
For&H3; say a Father do forget to&H9; show
The love by&H4; nature he doth owe his son,
In&H4; my opinion it is no&H2; sin at all,
If such a son cast off the awful duty
Which&H61; to&H4; his Father otherwise were due.
In&H4; all things just proportion must be kept.
If the king care not for&H4; the Common-wealth,
Why should the Common-wealth respect the king?
But to&H4; the purpose: how wilt thou contrive
The manner of his death?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why as I told your grace
In&H4; this days parley twixt the French and you,
Whilst you are busy, I will&H1; insert myself
Amongst the soldiers of that&H62; aged Earl,
And gathering near his person, suddenly
Thus send my poniard to&H4; his hateful breast.

sp.speaker: Hugo.
sp.l: What didst thou mean to&H9; wound our&Htp; General?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Silence Don Ugo, no&H2; such matter man,
He is a villain, and we&Htp; will&H1; use him so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am indifferent, had I spilt his blood,
It was my coming: but prevented thus:
Now Epernoune shall be the mark I aim at;
For&H3; one I vow, though to&H9; have slain them both
Had been exceeding good: how now my Lord?
Misconster not, I meant your grace no&H2; hurt,
Though mine enkindled fury when I thought
Of Epernoune, made me draw forth my poniard,
It was to&H9; show how resolute I am.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I know it was, sound we&Htp; parley then,
That&H3; Epernoune may know we&Htp; are in&H4; place,
Where conference was appointed to&H9; be had:
And as they march, fall thou in&H4; ring with them.
sp.stage: Enter Epernoune carried in his Chaire, and souldiers marching.
sp.l: Now Cripple what your legs refuse to&H9; do,
I know your hands will&H1; presently perform.
I mean, deliver me the Crown of France.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Raise me a little, fellows in&H4; my chair,
Hernando, what saidst thou? deliver thee
The Crown of France? why straggling Spaniard
What makes thee overween thy valour so&H52;?
Thinks thou because I seem a withered tree
That&H3; I am sapless quite? no&H7; Duke, there lives
Within this rivelled flint some sparks of fire,
Which&H61; if thou touch, will&H1; fly into thy face.
Nor do not thou contemn me for&H4; mine age,
This eye is not so&H51; dim, but I perceive
The marks of arrogance upon&H4; thy brow:
Aye, and for&H4; frown, I can return thee frown.
What glory not so&H51; much upon&H4; thy strength,
The day hath been this body which&H61; thou seest
Now falling to&H4; the earth, but for&H4; these props
Hath made as tall a soldier as yourself
Totter within his saddle: and this hand
Now shaking with the palsy, cask the beaver
Of my proud Foe, until he did forget
What ground he stood upon&H5;: go to&H5;, go to&H5;,
The Crown of France delivered to&H4; thy hand?
Good King, how is thy dignity blasphemed?
But do thy worst, I am his Substitute,
And though I cannot strike, yet with a beck
Can I raise up&H5; more fists about thine ears
Than thou hast hairs upon&H4; thy tawny scalp.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Am I reviled and baffled to&H4; my face,
And by&H4; a Dotard? one but for&H4; his tongue,
In&H4; whom there is no&H2; difference twixt himself,
A mere Anatomy, a Jack of lent,
And the pale Image of a bloodless ghost?
Yet doth he look as big as Hercules,
And would be thought to&H9; have a voice like&H4; thunder.
Well Epernoune, there is a privilege
That&H3; babes may speak their pleasure without check,
Else quickly should my sword break off this parley,
And with a fillip send thee to&H4; thy grave.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Callest he me back? it never shall be said,
But Epernoune will&H1; show himself a man,
And whilst the breath is in&H4; his nostrils, prove
A real substance, and maintain the right
Of Lewis of Fraunce, even by&H4; the dint of sword:
Lend me your hands, I will&H1; challenge him the fight.
Twit me with babe? lend me your hands I say.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: Ah good my Lord presume not, you are weak.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Weak knave? thou liest.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Get him a standing stool,
And then perhaps the child will&H1; learn to&H9; go.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Yet child again? alack it will&H1; not be,
My heart is good enough, but tyrant age
Benumbs those instruments with which&H61; my heart
Should execute the office of a Knight.
Medyna thou mayest thank the rigorous hands
Of strength-decaying age: these legs of mine
Had they not proved rebels to&H4; my mind,
Ere this I would have taught thee to&H9; usurp
Upon&H4; our&Htp; confines; but what they omit,
Here are both arms and legs to&H9; see performed.
Sirrah stand back, knowest thou what manners is?
To&H9; press so&H51; near the person of our&Htp; General?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am a soldier, wherefore may I not?
Shall every common soldier at a time
When serious matters are determined on&H5;,
Betwixt both Armies: impudently thrust
Into the secrets of his Prince? stand back.
Lay hands upon&H4; the villain, see within his fist,
A naked poniard.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: How now countrymen,
What unexpected mutiny is that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: A plague upon&H4; it, Don Vgo he is discovered.
Some treason as it seems my noble Lord,
This base companion since you first began
To&H9; sit in&H4; parley: hath at sundry times
Saucily presumed to&H9; undermine your talk,
And being reprehended for&H4; the same,
We&Htp; found this dagger hid within his sleeve.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Doubtless he meant to&H9; murder me,
Now God be thanked I have scaped his hands.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: List Epernoune, he is a man of mine,
Touch not a hair of him, lest for&H4; that&H62; hair
I send a hundred thousand of your souls
To&H9; dwell in&H4; darkness.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: How? a man of thine?
Unless I be deceived I know that&H62; face,
It is the Traitor Mercury, disguised.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Mercury my foe? had I but known so&H51; much
I would have made him sure enough ere this,
But Epernoune, mark what I say to&H4; thee,
If thou wilt redeliver to&H4; my hands
That&H62; juggling Duke, as I am Gentleman
And true to&H4; Spain, I will&H1; depart your land.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Deliver him? not for&H4; the wealth of Spain.
Not for&H4; the treasure you do yearly bag
From both the Indies: but Meayna say,
What reason moved thee term the Duke thy man?
And wherefore didst thou mention redelivery,
As though sometime he had been in&H4; thy hand?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I will&H1; tell thee Epernoune, as I am Knight,
Not swerving from the truth in&H4; any point,
And keeping faith accordingly reward
His traitorous purpose, which&H61; is all I crave.
This morning he was brought unto my Tent,
Where being admitted, openly he showed
How he had been disgraced and wronged by&H4; thee,
For&H4; which&H61; he promised, if I would consent
In&H4; this day's parley, he would murder thee.
I seeing his resolution, was persuaded:
And promising, I needs must say, reward,
Though I do know when he had done the deed,
How I was minded to&H9; have dealt with him,
He thrust himself amongst thy followers,
And what the peril is you see yourselves,
But all this while I knew not who&H61; he was,
More than a private discontented person,
For&H3; if I had, the wretch had never lived
To&H9; be an eye-sore to&H4; his countrymen.
O bloody practise, soldiers join with me,
And we&Htp; will&H1; tear him piecemeal with our&Htp; hands.

sp.speaker: All the rest.
sp.l: Agreed: let him not live a minute longer.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Pacify yourselves, not one of you
On&H4; pain of our&Hrp; displeasure, once offer
To&H9; touch a limb of him: Ingrateful Duke,
Wherein hath Epernoune deserved thy hate,
That&H3; thou shouldst basely seek to&H9; murder him?
But wherefore ask I that&H62;? when it is well known,
Thou didst as wrongfully pursue the life
Of noble Lodwick, that&H62; true Gentleman,
That&H62; very map of honourable carriage.
Amend, amend, be sorry for&H4; thy fault,
That&H3; though thy body perish by&H4; the law,
Thy wretched soul may have a place in&H4; heaven.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Tell not me Epernoune of heaven nor hell,
I am a Peer, and Regent of this Realm,
And thus you ought not to&H9; entreat a Prince.

sp.speaker: All Soul.
sp.l: Thou Regent of the Realm? speak that&H62; again,
And we&Htp; will&H1; slit thy weasand with our&Htp; swords.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Soldiers forbear.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Nay Epernoune show justice,
Upon&H4; that&H62; caitiff, that&H62; perjured slave,
That&H62; coward Duke, or here I do protest,
For&H4; ever I will&H1; speak in&H4; thy dispraise,
Reporting to&H4; the world thou art no&H2; Knight,
Nor worthy of the name of Epernoune.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: My Lord, I may not take upon&H4; myself,
To&H9; be his judge, he is a Peer of Fraunce,
And must have open trial by&H4; his Peers,
But when the King my master doth return,
As shortly we&Htp; are told he means to&H9; do,
At his discretion be his punishment.
Mean space Medyna I can do no&H2; mote,
But see him safely kept in&H4; Iron bands.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Now that&H3; as thou art Knight, and for&H4; this day
I do proclaim a solemn truce with thee,
And not a sword of ours&Htp; shall hurt the French.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: As I am Knight, and liege-man to&H4; the King,
He shall be kept in&H4; fetters till he come.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It is enough: now back unto our&Htp; Tents.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: And we&Htp; unto the City whence we&Htp; came,
And for&H4; our&Htp; safety, praise Jehova's name.

div2.stage: Enter Uilliers the Merchant, with Oriana and Diana.

sp.speaker: Oriana.
sp.l: How shall we&Htp; gentle Sir requite the grace
Which&H61; in&H4; so&H51; great necessity we&Htp; find
At your kind hands? but with our&Htp; daily prayers,
Implore the heavens for&H4; your prosperity?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Which&H61; we&Htp; will&H1; never cease to&H9; do, so&H51; long
As life remains in&H4; our&Htp; distressed bodies.

sp.speaker: Uil.
sp.l: These words are needless, what I do to&H4; you,
The duty of a Christian binds me to&H5;.
Remember then the promise you have made,
That&H3; if your husband live not, whom yourselves
Do verily imagine to&H9; be dead,
That&H3; then you are my wife.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: That&H62; promise I will&H1; keep
Unfeignedly, with hearty thanks to&H4; heaven,
That&H3; if my husband do not breathe this life,
My misery yet sorts me at the last
A second choice, so&H51; loving and so&H51; kind.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And I right willingly shall call him Father,
That&H61; in&H4; such virtuous sort respects our&Htp; need,
Without impeachment of our&Htp; honest fame,
Debarring wicked lust to&H9; blot the same.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: When I do otherwise, then as beseems
The reputation both of yourselves and me,
Convert your love to&H4; me, to&H4; deadly hate,
And may all tongues condemn me with reproof.
Come in&H5; then, take possession of your own,
My lands, my house, my goods and all is yours,
Only my sisters portion, which&H61; I have,
Upon&H4; our&Htp; troth-plight vow of marriage,
(If so&H52; your husband live not,) set apart
And ordered in&H4; a readiness for&H4; her&H6;.
Come lovely mother, and thy virtuous child,
When angry storms are past, the heavens do smile.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Thus Ferdinand I see that&H3; we&Htp; must part.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Our&Htp; needy state enforceth it sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Will&H1; you to&H4; Fraunce?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: To&H4; Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: And to&H4; the war?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: To&H4; my advancement, war must be the mean,
I cannot dig, I have no&H2; handy-craft:
Our&Htp; coin is spent, and yet I cannot crave,
And thought of want, your want doth wound my soul,
When I consider what you are.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: O peace.
What am I but the wife of Ferdinand,
By&H4; love and faith unto thy fortunes bound?
O let me follow thee to&H4; those French wars

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O prize your honour and my credit more,
Were it convenient, we&Htp; would not divide:
But as it is. I must go, you must bide.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: So&H52; says discretion, but true love repines,
That&H3; want should sever those whom he combines,
But pardon sweet, my speech is spent in&H4; vain,
You must depart, when will&H1; ye come again?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Soon, if success do answer my desire.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: You will&H1; write to&H4; me?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: As oft as I can send.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: You will&H1; leave me here?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: With this assured friend,
Whose kindness in&H4; abundance we&Htp; have found.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Alas good sir, my means are weak ye know,
In&H4; sooth I am no&H2; richer than I show:
Were wishes wealth, your want should be supplied,
And have no&H2; power your persons to&H9; divide.
For&H3; I protest, in&H4; all my life before,
I never saw two whom I affected more.
But this adds weight to&H4; mourners leaden grief,
Words may bemoan, but cannot give relief.
For&H3; part you must, extremity to&H9; shun,
In&H4; wars is wealth and honour to&H9; be won.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: And fame, and death, and then am I undone.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why death dwells here, you see my daily trade,
For&H4; men of peace how many graves are made:
Your spouse with wealth and worship may return,
And bring you joy, that&H61; at his parting mourn.
Hope so&H52;, and hinder not his good intent,
That&H3; for&H4; his honour, and your welfare's meant.
O that&H3; my cottage where ye must remain,
Were (for&H4; your sake) the gloriousest house in&H4; Spain:
But as it is, your own it is, and I
Your poor poor host will&H1; tend you carefully.
But I am tedious in&H4; persuasion,
And you foreslow the present times occasion.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: O do not mount him on&H4; the wings of haste
That&H61; goes too soon.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Dearest, mine hour is past,
You gave me leave to&H9; go, revoke it not,
By&H4; lingering here there is no&H2; good fortune got.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: You will&H1; wear my favour?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Else let heaven hate me.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Farewell sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Dear Love God comfort thee.
Father, I leave my Jewel in&H4; your hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I will&H1; be careful.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Sweet heart, Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What says Odillia?

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Nothing but God-buoy ye.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Such loath farewell my wife and daughter took:
God bless them both, and send us&Htp; well to&H9; meet.
Take comfort Lady, though this hour be sad,
