His safe return with wealth, may make you glad.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas and Bunch: Sir Nicholas hath a Paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Sexton, I have sought thee in&H4; every seat in&H4; the Church, doubting thou hadst been drowsy, and fallen a sleep in&H4; some pew.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: I will&H1; be sworn from the Chancel to&H4; the Belfry ye have sought him, and in&H4; the Steeple, for&H4; fear he had been crept into a Bell, and been asleep: Lord how do you mistress? fie, why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Fair Lady, let pass mourning for&H4; the absent; it is like&H4; sorrowing for&H4; the dead: either Idolatry or Hypocrisy, I cannot tell which&H61;: I could preach patience to&H4; ye, but your own wit is as much as my learning: your husbands absence you must bear; yea and bear him also; in&H4; mind I mean: there be but three things that&H61; save us&Htp; or condemn us&Htp;: that&H62; is, thoughts, words, and deeds: and you may have comfort in&H4; all, and so&H3; be saved in&H4; them all; your own good thoughts a good comfort: your friends good words, a better comfort: and your husbands good deeds at his return, the best comfort. Thus much for&H4; instruction. Command my service day and night, to&H9; ride and run to&H9; do ye good.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: So&H3; Master. Vicar, I am glad ye have done.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: For&H4; this time and place I have, because I have somewhat to&H9; say to&H4; my Sexton: here is a thing in&H4; writing (Sexton) that&H61; is sent to&H9; be published through all the French Kings dominions. Read it, let me hear it, and then thou shalt know my mind.

To&H4; all Christians, and especially to&H4; the Kings Liege-people, Lord Epernoune and the rest of the French Nobility send greeting: whereas the thrice noble, and renowned Prince Lodowick Duke of Bulloigne, was by&H4; the Kings Majesty (at his departure to&H9; go on&H4; his devoted pilgrimage to&H4; the blessed Sepulchre) appointed Joint-Governor, Regent, and Protector of the Realm of Fraunce: together with that&H62; pernicious Arch-traitor Mercurie, Duke of Aniou during the Kings absence. And that&H3; the said noble Duke of Bulloigne was by&H4; the treacherous, unjust, and unlawful Force of the said Mercury, expulsed out of his Dukedom, Lands, Territories, and Revenues, and dispossessed of his place, if not of his life. For&H3; as much as the said notorious malefactor Mercurie, hath sithence proved himself an open enemy unto his native Country and King. We&Htp; have thought good to&H9; publish and proclaim, that&H3; whosoever can bring true notice of the safety and life of the said Duke Lodwick, shall have twenty thousand Crowns. And he that&H61; doth present him alive, shall have fifty thousand Crowns. To&H4; the end that&H3; the said most honourable virtuous Duke may be fully repossessed and restored to&H4; all his Lands, Liberties and places of authority in&H4; this Realm of Fraunce. Dated the last of May, and Subscribed by&H4; Epernoune and other.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: By&H4; my holy orders thou art as well worthy to&H9; be a Vicar as myself, thou readest so&H51; well: I prithee soon at Evensong read this to&H4; the Parishioners, I cannot be there, for&H3; I have promised to&H9; bowl a match with good fellows this afternoon at Guynes for&H4; a wager, wet and dry, viz. two gallons of Gascoyne wine, and two French Crowns, I can stay no&H2; longer, I fear they stay for&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: By&H4; this light I never saw him make such haste into the Pulpit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hear me one word good master ere ye go,
And grant me one petition, which&H61; is short.
All these French Crowns dare I assure mine own:
For&H3; I do know where that&H62; poor Duke remains,
And will&H1; present him to&H4; old Epernoune.
My suit is, that&H3; you will&H1; take this honest Bunch
To&H9; be your Sexton whilst I am away.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: I am content, give Bunch the Church door key,
Upon&H4; condition thou wilt say
Evensong to&H4; the Parish this afternoon,
And read that&H62; publication to&H4; them.
Then go thy way tomorrow if thou wilt:
Lord how time passes: In&H4; my conscience I burn day-light,
It is one o'clock at least. Fare ye well, fare ye well,
I come i'faith lads, I come, though I come late,
I hope to&H9; lie as near the Mistress as any of ye all.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Well, I see I shall have your office, and I trust you will&H1; bestow your spade and your pick-axe upon&H4; me, that&H3; I may grind them sharpe, to&H9; dispatch a grave quickly. And I pray you as ye travel up&H5; into high Fraunce, send the plague and the pox, and as many diseases as you can, down into this Country to&H9; kill the people, that&H3; I may get money for&H4; their graves making.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here take the key, and toll to&H4; Evening prayer,
I will&H1; do my master's bidding ere I go.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
Odil.
sp.l: And will&H1; you go and leave me here alone
My only friend, now Ferdinand is gone?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ask of your thoughts if they can counsel keep:
Which&H61; if upon&H4; your honour you assure,
You shall partake a secret very strange.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: My faith and honour be engaged for&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Exterior shows express not always truth,
Nor do imaginations ever fail:
My Sextons case doth cloud Nobility.
And (if opinion do not reason wrong)
Rich noble blood flows through your pure clear veins,
Which&H61; conceit draws these secrets from my soul.
That&H62; fortunes scorn, that&H62; sorrow-tossed Duke
Lodwick of Bulloigne tells this tale to&H4; you
That&H61; can conceive, conceal, and counsel me.
Say Lady, (for&H3; I know you are no&H2; less)
Have I not cause when Proclamation tells,
That&H3; Lodwick shall receive redress of wrongs?
To&H9; claim the due that&H61; thereunto belongs?
Odil.
Great cause my Lord, and I to&H9; be content,
In&H4; this poor Coat to&H9; rest me patient,
Until my husband come or send for&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O had these tidings come ere he had gone,
Then he nor I had travelled alone:
For&H3; Lady, I affirm it constantly,
I love the Gentleman religiously,
Which&H61; in&H4; my bettered fortunes he shall find,
And then to&H4; you I purpose to&H9; be kind:
Then what you are, speak freely your fair mind.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Emanuell Duke of Brabant called me child,
Till him for&H4; love my Ferdinand beguiled.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I said and knew ye were no&H2; vulgar Dame,
For&H3; sparks of honour will&H1; burst into flame:
Hapless Odillia, but most fortunate,
Compared with my poor wives and daughters state.
Odil.
Where be those Ladies? let me them attend.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O knew I where, all grief were at an end:
I hear, that&H3; London is their mansion place.
Odil.
But shall they not be sent for&H5; by&H4; your grace?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Not yet Odillia, first I will&H1; visit France:
Where if good stars my state do readvance,
And grant me power to&H9; free my native soil,
From those that&H61; now her&H2; wealth and beauty spoil:
I may with comfort then call home my Joy,
Till then, their sight will&H1; but revive annoy.
Odil.
What can you prize so&H51; highly as their sight?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Women discern not men's affairs aright:
I prize mine honour, and my country's good,
More than wife, children, or my proper blood.
Hark the Bell tolls, the Sexton I must play
By&H4; promise once, tomorrow I will&H1; away.
Let me receive some token at your hand,
That&H61; I may carry unto Ferdinand:
And this forget not, for&H4; a small end,
To&H9; come to&H4; us&Htp; if we&Htp; for&H4; you do send.

div2.stage: Enter Epernoune brought in, in his chayre.

sp.l: So&H3; from this place I shall behold the fight
Betwixt both Armies: now go one of you,
And with our&Htp; Leaders presently give charge,
The other stay with me: O might the sight
Of Epernoune, be like&H4; the noontide Sun,
With the reflection of his feeble eye,
To&H9; melt like&H4; wax the courage of our&Htp; foes,
And make the French men stiff as Adamant:
Then could my heart excuse mine idle hands,
That&H3; they bear not a part in&H4; this conflict.
But now defiance from each party flies.
sp.stage: Sound Trumpet first. Enter Ferdinand pursuing Don Hugo, cutting him soundly.
sp.l: A valiant Gentleman whatever thou art,
And by&H4; mine honour very nobly fought:
I have not seen in&H4; all my life before,
So&H51; young, a tender, and effeminate face,
Father such rough and manly fortitude,
How like&H4; a weighty hammer did his sword
Fall on&H4; the Spaniards shrinking burganet?
That&H3; had he not betook him to&H4; his heels,
This hour had been his latest hour of life.
sp.stage: Alarum. Enter Ferdinand againe, pursuing Don Hugo.
sp.l: What still in&H4; chase? he will&H1; not give him over
Till he hath slain, or made him yield I see:
A right begotten cockerel of the game.
Whence may he come? as I remember me,
I never saw him in&H4; our&Htp; camp till now.
I prithee go range, through our&Htp; battle ranks,
And when you overtake him, gently crave
He will&H1; vouchsafe to&H9; come and speak with me.
My heart's enamoured on&H4; his valorous deeds,
Spaniard, some more of such a haughty breed,
Would make the stoutest of your hearts to&H9; bleed.
And here he comes, fair bud of Chivalry.
Welcome to&H4; Epernoune, give me your hand,
I thank you even with all my very heart,
For&H4; this good service you have done today.
Are you of Fraunce I pray you, or what place,
Is honoured by&H4; your noble parentage?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am (my Lord) the Duke of Brabants subject,
A younger brother, whose inheritance
Is little more than what his sword shall purchase,
And for&H4; that&H62; cause, admonished of these wars
Between the haughty Spaniard and this Realm,
The noble Burbon gave me entertain.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Are you his soldier? trust me for&H4; his sake,
I love you better than I did before,
And for&H4; some confirmation of my love,
Take this in&H4; earnest of a greater good.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Lordship, and will&H1; rest
A faithful servitor to&H4; Fraunce and you.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Nay stay a while, refresh your weary limbs,
A little intermission will&H1; do well,
Amidst these sweating gorbellies: holy rood
There runs a thought into my labouring mind,
Which&H61; from my heart sends gladness to&H4; mine eyes.
Methinks the more I view this Gentleman,
The more he doth resemble Bulloignes Duke,
The virtuous Lodwick both for&H4; face and limb,
When he and I were fellow-mates in&H4; arms,
Against the Turk, such deeds of hardiment,
Did Lodwick show as he hath done this day.
Even such a gesture had he when he talked,
As mild and affable in&H4; time of peace,
As he was stern and boisterous in&H4; the wars.
All these apparent in&H4; this towardly youth,
Earl Lodowicks want doth wet my cheeks with ruth.
sp.stage: A shoute within, enter a Souldier.
sp.l: What means this cheerful shout?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My Lord,
The battle of the Spaniards is dispersed:
Beside, I bring to&H4; you this happy news,
The worthy Duke of Bulloigne long desired,
And much bewailed for&H4; his injury,
Lives and returned about an hour since.
At his first coming, armed in&H4; complete steel,
Challenged the Duke Medyna at his Tent,
And there in&H4; single combat like&H4; himself,
And like&H4; a father of his country's weal,
Hath slain that&H62; proud disturber of our&Htp; peace:
For&H4; which&H61; the Soldiers as you heard my Lord,
Did fill the air with their applausive shouts:
Thronging about him in&H4; such clustering heaps,
To&H9; see his face and do him reverence,
As scarce he hath free passage to&H4; this place.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: O that&H3; I had or legs, or wings to&H9; fly,
That&H3; I might quickly satisfy mine eye
With sight of him whose company is more worth
Than heaps of countless, and unvalued Treasure.
But where is the other Leader of that&H62; route,
Surnamed Don Ugo, is he scaped the field?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: This Gentleman before Medyna died,
Gave him his passport to&H4; his longest home.
But my good Lord, I almost had forgot
The latter part of my behooveful message,
There is a stranger Duke of whence, my haste
Suffered me not to&H9; be instructed,
That&H61; likewise came with aid unto our&Htp; Camp,
And is well known unto my Lord of Bulloigne.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Now if I were enclosed within my grave,
I would as willingly forsake the world,
As woeful prisoners many years detained
In&H4; dark obscurity, could be content
To&H9; change the dungeon for&H4; a public walk.
But first let us&Htp; embrace our&Htp; loving friend.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Your honour may sit still, he is coming hither.

div2.stage: Enter Lodwick, Emanuell Duke of Brabant with souldiers.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Right worthy Duke, whose victories ever shone
Through clouds of envy, and disaster change,
Make rich my bosom with embalming thee,
And wherein ought my restrains my faltering tongue
Let vows for&H4; words distinguish my content.
Welcome, o welcome to&H4; ungoverned Fraunce,
Whose working garment of afflicting war,
Is now cast off, and she hath girt herself
In&H4; peaceful robes of holiday attire.
And you my Lord of Brabant as I think?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Your friend Lord Epernoune in&H4; what he may.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Welcome in&H4; sooth, your presence with the rest,
Hath made me happy, and my country blessed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: These greetings reverend Earl, exceed desert,
Had it been Lodwicks fortune to&H9; have done
Ten times more service than this day's exploit:
It might not be sufficient to&H9; redeem
The lack of his endeavours all this while.
But heaven and you I hope will&H1; pardon me,
Considering I was forced from hence to&H9; fly.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Aye and most wrongfully enforced my Lord,
But he that&H61; was the author of that&H62; ill,
The traitorous Duke of Aniou, by&H4; just heavens,
Now at your mercy stands, one fetch him forth,
And Lodwick repossessed in&H4; the place,
If that&H62; authority his highness gave;
Judge and condemn according as you please.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No&H7;, let him still be prisoner where he is,
Your wisdom hath discovered his abuse,
And our&Htp; dread Sovereign shall determine it:
Were it my wrongs were greater than they are
I will&H1; not be a factor for&H4; myself.
Now, what is he my Lord of all this train,
By&H4; whom our&Htp; other enemy was slain?
Don Ugo de Cordoua: fain would I
Know that&H62; brave Gentleman, and for&H4; the same,
Add somewhat more unto his honoured name.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Therein my Lord, I shall account myself,
Much pleasured by&H4; your grace: and this is he,
My Lord of Brabants subject as he said.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My subject? traitorous villain how he lies,
But I will&H1; be revenged upon&H4; his crimes.
What may I call your name young Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My name is Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know it well,
And little thinks he it is the Sextons hands
Draws forth a sword to&H9; give him Knight-hood here:
But I am glad it is my fortunes chance,
To&H9; be of power to&H9; show him any grace,
Whom I admired when first I saw his face.
Kneel down young Ferdinand, and now again,
Rise up&H5; Sir Ferdinando, Lodwicks Knight.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And rise withal base Ferdinand, false wretch,
Viler than puddle dirt, thou spring of hate:
Never begot but of some dunghill churl.
Durst thou avow thou wast my subject? durst
That&H62; impious tongue pronounce my name,
Whom thou hast most ingratefully incensed?
Villain, more abject than thought can decipher,
But I am glad that&H3; we&Htp; are met at last.
Here in&H4; this presence I do challenge thee
Of most notorious felony and theft:
Let me have justice on&H4; this fugitive
You Peers of Fraunce, or else you injure me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What moves the noble Brabant to&H4; this rage?

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: O wherefore stain you virtue and renown
With such foul terms of ignominy and shame?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Virtue my Lords? you guild a rotten stick,
You spread fair honours garments on&H4; the ground,
And dignify a loathsome swine with Pearl.
This shadow of a seeming Gentleman,
This gloss of piety, deceives your sight:
He is nothing so&H52;, nor so&H52;, but one my Lords,
Whom I have fostered in&H4; my Court of alms.
And to&H9; requite my careful indulgence,
Hath Judas-like betrayed his master's life,
And stolen mine only daughter to&H9; allay
The sensual fire of his enkindled lust:
For&H4; which&H61;, let me have justice, and the law.
Lod.
You shall have justice, though I cannot think,
So&H51; fair a shape hath had so&H51; foul a forge.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Alack the day, misfortune should so&H51; soon
Disturb our&Htp; friendship was so&H51; well begun:
Come hither Ferdinand, and tell me truth
If thou be guilty as the Duke informs?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I not deny my Lord, but I am married
Unto Odillia, though unworthy far
Of such a gracious blessing: yet her&H2; love
Was forward in&H4; the choice as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: See how he goes about to&H9; cloak the fact
With love and marriage? no&H2; adulterous swain,
Your hedge-betrothing covenant shall not serve.
Where is your sweet companion, where is she?
But we&Htp; will&H1; talk of that&H62; an other time.
Why is my Lord of Bulloigne so&H51; remiss,
And will&H1; not presently be given in&H4; charge,
A pair of bolts be clapped upon&H4; his heels?
Lod.
Without offence my Lord unto your grace,
Myself will&H1; undertake to&H9; be his bail,
And he shall answer if you so&H52; be pleased,
Your accusation when you will&H1; appoint
A day of hearing; be it tomorrow next.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And even tomorrow let his trial be,
I will&H1; no&H2; longer have the cause deferred.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: And Ferdinando, in&H4; this time of need,
Old Epernoune will&H1; stand thee in&H4; some steed.
Good Duke of Bullen, use him kindly yet,
Whilst I do follow this incensed Lord,
And try if tears may drive him to&H4; accord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now Ferdinand, here is none but you and I,
Know you not me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cannot call it to&H4; my mind my Lord,
That&H3; ever I did see your grace till now.
Lod.
Bethink yourself, look better on&H4; my face.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There is my Lord, with pardon be it spoke,
A man in&H4; Ards, a Sexton of a Church,
With whom I had acquaintance, he methinks
Is somewhat like&H4; your excellence, or else
I do not know where I have seen your favour.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The Sexton there is Duke of Bulloigne here:
Be not abashed, it was I to&H4; whom you left
Your fair Odilliæ, and it is I can witness,
That&H3; you and she are lawful man and wife.
This may be some defence against the stream
Of angry Brabant, that&H61; pursues your life.
Come, I have send in&H4; private for&H4; the dame,
And by&H4; all means to&H9; shield you both from shame.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas with a Letter, Odillia with a Letter in her hand, Bunch, and Nuntio.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: And must we&Htp; thus (fair Lady) forgo your sweet company?

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: You see my Lord of Bulloigne sends for&H4; me,
With him remains my husband Ferdinand,
So&H3; you perceive how much it me concerns,
To&H9; leave this place to&H9; better my estate.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I cannot blame a fair Lady, to&H9; leave a bad thing to&H9; go to&H4; a better: my friend, thank the Duke of Bulloigne, my quondam Sexton for&H4; his kind Letter. I may say that&H3;, never a Priest in&H4; Picardie can say beside, that&H3; I have had a Duke to&H4; my Sexton, be it spoken without pride.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: The Devil ye have? was he not my petticessor I pray ye? I was his acquaintance afore he knew you, friend, do my condemnations to&H4; him, one Bunch that&H61; botched in&H4; his City, ran away in&H4; his company, and dwelt where he dwelt, with Dutch Yacob Smelt. And for&H4; my better grace, ye may say Barnabie Bunch that&H61; has his Sextons place. Hark ye friend, you have brought no&H2; diseases with ye, have ye?

sp.speaker: Nuntio.
sp.l: Why dost thou ask so&H51; fond a question?

sp.speaker: Bunc.
sp.p: Marry I spake to&H4; him when he went, to&H9; send the plague or the pox or some disease of high France, down into this low Country, to&H9; lay the men of Ards low, that&H3; that&H62; I may have money for&H4; their graves, and marry one of their wives, if ye have any infirmity about ye, as the stone, or the dropsy, the pip, or the palsy, I will&H1; give ye as much for&H4; it as another to&H9; have it left in&H4; our&Htp; Parish.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Will&H1; ye not write Sir Nicholas to&H4; the Duke?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: To&H9; tell ye true Lady, a Letter of six lines, is three day's work for&H4; me. The Duke knows my mind as well as if I did write: if he have a better Benefice or two for&H4; me, tell him I will&H1; come.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Then we&Htp; come, both the Vicar and the Sexton.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: Why Bunch, I thought you would have gone with me.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.p: Truly not thus advised, if ye had no&H2; husband. so&H52;: but having a husband, no&H7;. I can be but well, and the hardest of my my learning is past: I can say Amen without book, chime two Bells at once, whip a dog with both hands, know the difference of the strokes in&H4; tolling for&H4; men and women: grease the Bell-ropes, turn the clappers, sweep the church, help the Vicar on&H5; with his surplice. All this I have by&H4; rote ye may tell the Duke, as if I had been bound prentice to&H4; the Trade: and for&H4; making a grave, come all Picardie for&H4; the price of my pickaxe.

sp.speaker: Odil.
sp.l: We&Htp; stay too long, Sir Nicholas, farewell,
And farewell Bunch.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Heartily to&H4; you: pray ye condemn me to&H4; your husband
Master. farting Androw.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Ferdinando, Bunch, thou mistermest his name.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: So&H52; have you done many a one in&H4; the first lesson, God forgive ye.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Let that&H62; pass amongst the rest of my venial sins,
And tell me Bunch, tell me, where is the best liquor?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: At the green Dragon gentle master Vicar.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Will&H1; the Dragon sting?

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: From the head to&H4; the heel,
He will&H1; sting your brain so&H52;, that&H3; he will&H1; make your seat reel.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; go play for&H4; two pots, away Bunch away.

sp.speaker: Bunch.
sp.l: Then the Parish is like&H5; to&H9; have no&H2; service today.

div2.stage: Enter Lodwick, Emanuell, Epernoune in his chaire, Frederick with the Prouost and a Headsman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lord of Bulloigne, many things might urge
Your speed of Justice, for&H4; so&H51; just a wrong,
As the regard of your own princely state,
In&H4; case of him that&H61; is an equal Peer,
The right of Princes, which&H61; should under-prop
An honourable and direct revenge.
I could perhaps say, were it not in&H4; Justice,
The blood of Brabant, should deserve of Bulloigne:
But I disrobe and strip off all regard,
And lay my wrongs as nakedly before you,
As comes an Infant born into the world.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My Lord of Brabant, what I freely urge,
Is not to&H9; stop or turn the course of Justice,
Which&H61; must sway all our&Htp; actions, and must stand
Steady and fixed in&H4; one certain point:
But only be entreaty to&H4; your grace,
To&H9; supple your proceeding in&H4; this case.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: My Lord of Brabant, may old Epernoune
By&H4; license of my Lord, the Duke of Bulloigne
Have leave to&H9; speak, an old fool that&H61; I am,
By&H4; your good patience let me say my mind.
Now by&H4; my troth I cannot speak for&H4; tears.
Alas, alas, there is something I would say,
Now God help age, would I were in&H4; my grave.
Justice may cut off Ferdinand, where is he?
O art thou there poor man? alas, alas:
Justice may cut him off, I will&H1; not deny,
But turn him with his sword amongst his foes,
And he that&H61; buys his life shall buy it dear.
Alas poor boy, would I could do thee good:
O to&H9; see him lead an Army in&H4; the field,
Would make a man young, were as old as I.
I would thou hadst died where I saw thee last,
Even in&H4; the midst of all the Spanish Army,
On&H4; that&H62; condition I had died with thee:
God help, God help, an ill mischance soon falls,
And still the weakest go unto the walls.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Defer me not my Lord, let me have Justice.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My Lord you must have Justice, that&H62; you know,
But yet my Lord of Brabant, might our&Htp; love
Rebate this sharpe edge of your bitter wrath:
With what an easy sweetness should our&Htp; judgment
Be relished of every gentle heart?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lord of Bulloigne urge me not with pity,
He against whom I am thus pitiless
Robbed me of pity: proceed unto your judgment.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: God help, pity is banished from the earth I see,
Thou pitiest none, nor no&H2; man pities thee.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Old man thou dotest.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Thou art a naughty Lord, I tell thee Brabant,
The day hath been thou durst not tell me so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Have patience gentle father, true noble Lord,
He will&H1; have death: who&H62; is there?
Command the Lady presently be brought.

div2.stage: Lodwick ascends, the Lady is brought in.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Lodwick of Bulloigne, is it not enough
Thou hast delayed me in&H4; the case of Justice,
But bringest this hateful whore unto my sight
To&H9; vex and grieve my soul? I tell thee Bulloigne,
Thou wrongest mine honour with indignity.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Ah were it any tongue that&H61; called thee so&H52;
But his Odillia, I would make that&H62; word
Heretical and full of blasphemy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lord of Bulloigne, I will&H1; not abide her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My Lord you must abide her&H6;, since for&H4; her&H6;
You seek the life of this young Ferdinand,
Sift law so&H51; strictly, follow the offence,
Take all advantage of your evidence.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Now by&H4; my troth a goodly wench indeed:
Alas poor Earl, fair Princess speak thy mind
And I will&H1; stand by&H4; thy side, and yet I cannot,
Ah this whoreson age, well, well.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will&H1; not hear her&H6; speak.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: All is one my Lord of Brabant, we&Htp; will&H1; hear her&H6;:
Speak freely Princess, and without control.

sp.speaker: Odis.
sp.l: Right reverend Lord, if only for&H4; my sake,
My father seek the death of Ferdinand,
I here acquit my husband of the fault,
Although I cannot of the punishment.
I was the thief, I was the ravisher,
And I am only guilty of the fact.
How like&H4; a robber did I lie in&H4; wait
With beauty to&H9; entrap his gentle youth?
And like&H4; a spirit when he hath walked alone,
How was I ever tempting him to&H9; love?
How with my favour did I work his breast,
Which&H61; at the first was stubborn, Iron, cold,
Till I brought his heart to&H4; supple temper,
To&H9; take the soft impression of affection?
With these allurements would I oft entice him,
Though thou be base, my love shall make thee noble:
Though thou be poor, my power shall make thee rich:
Though thou be scorned, my state shall make thee reverenced.
Let any of you all think with himself,
Were he so&H51; mean, so&H51; friendless, and unknown.
Wooed by&H4; a virgin Princess of my birth,
So&H51; young, so&H51; great, so&H51; rich, as is myself:
Thinks he, he would not do as he hath done?
He is guiltless of the fault: I was the cause,
Let me endure the rigour of your laws.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O thou dost wound my love with too much loving.
Thy beauty is not prized but with death:
That&H62; man hath not a soul, that&H61; would not die,
One hour to&H9; enjoy thy blessed company.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Nay, I must weep out these poor eyes are left,
I never saw a cause so&H51; full of pity.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lord proceed, the law adjudges death
To&H4; him that&H61; steals the heir of any Prince,
That&H61; is not a Prince that&H61; doth commit the act.
He is my slave, one that&H61; was found by&H4; me
Being a child, not fully two years old,
And as it should seem, begot in&H4; bastardy,
And by&H4; the parents to&H4; that&H62; wicked fruit,
Left in&H4; the River's sedges, there to&H9; be drowned,
What time the wars in&H4; Burgundy fell out,
And that&H3; my Duchess perished in&H4; the flight,
Nor never did I know what was his name,
Being so&H51; young, he could not tell the same:
Only upon&H4; his muckender and band, he had an F.
By&H4; which&H61; I did suppose his name was Ferdinand,
And so&H52; I named him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O blessed heaven, what sound is this I hear?
My little boy was lost even at that&H62; time:
Just of that&H62; age, and by&H4; that&H62; River's side,
Whose name was christened Fredericke, by&H4; my father,
And had an F. on&H4; everything he wore.
It is my son, be silent yet a while.
My Lord of Brabant, then I take exception
Both unto your indictment, and your plea.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: As how my Lord of Bulloigne? do me justice.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He is incited by&H4; the name of Ferdinand,
And I will&H1; prove him christened Fredericke,
And thus is your indictment overthrown.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It is a fallacy my Lord of Bulloigne,
He hath been ever called by&H4; that&H62; name.
Bulloigne, do me Justice, or by&H4; heaven
It is not Fraunce shall hold thee, impious Duke.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay if ye be so&H51; hot my Lord of Brabant,
Then to&H4; your plea that&H61; doth concern him most.
The law is this, that&H3; he shall lose his head,
That&H61; steals away the heir of any Prince,
If not a Prince that&H61; doth commit the rape.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So&H52; is my plea.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I grant but void in&H4; this.
He is a Prince that&H61; stole away thy daughter,
This is not Ferdinand, but Frederick:
The heir of Bulloigne, and my only son,
Ah my sweet boy, ah my dear Frederick:
Here now I stand, and here doth stand my boy,
In&H4; Christendom let any two that&H61; dare
Aver it to&H4; the father and the son,
That&H3; he is not as great a Prince as Brabant.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Nay I will&H1; be one, any three whatever they be,
And Brabant be thou one to&H9; answer us&Htp;,
Some honest man help me to&H4; Frederick.
For&H4; joy I shall weep out mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Bulloigne, how dost thou know him for&H4; thy son?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why Cousin Brabant, you say you found him
Hid in&H4; the sedges by&H4; the River: even at that&H62; instant,
And at the very place, the Duchess my dear sister perished:
With whom my little boy was at that&H62; time,
The place, the instant, and his certain age,
The letters set to&H9; signify his name,
The very manner of your finding him
When you departed from me with your Army,
In&H4; the pursuit of traitorous Mercurie.
These all affirm that&H3; he is only mine.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My Lord of Bulloigne, I embrace your love,
In&H4; all firm and true brotherly affection:
I make your son my son, my daughter yours,
And do entreat in&H4; Princely courtesy,
Old grief henceforth, no&H2; more be thought upon&H5;.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Dear brother Brabant, your true princely kindness
Doth but forestall, what I would have requested.
Right noble Prince, I give you Frederick,
And I accept your sweet Odillia.
Come, thou art now the Duke of Bulloignes daughter,
Thy husband is the Duke of Brabants son,
Thou shalt be now my care, my son thy fathers.
Thus do we&Htp; make exchange betwixt each others,
Thus should it be, betwixt two loving brothers.

sp.speaker: Eper.
sp.l: Nay, nay, let me be one I pray you Lords,
I have no&H2; child left to&H9; inherit mine
When I shall die, as long I cannot live,
I freely give them all that&H61; ere I have.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A thousand thanks, true noble Epernoune:
Brother of Brabant, Frederick, and fair Princess,
Embrace this noble Lord, and hold him dear.

sp.speaker: All together.
sp.l: Our&Htp; father, guide, and comfort we&Htp; you call,
And be you ever honoured of us&Htp; all.

sp.speaker: Uil.
sp.l: Justice my Lord of Bulloigne, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: My friend, what is thy cause, then let us&Htp; know,
Sit down good brother Brabant, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Uil.
sp.l: My Lord, my suit is here against a widow
That&H61; I have long time sued in&H4; way of marriage.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.l: Let me with judgment view this woman well.
Stay let me see, it is my Oriana,
And my poor Dyan, my dear loved Girl.
Alas poor souls, what woe and misery
Have ye endured since I left you last?
I will&H1; forbear my knowledge till I see
To&H4; what effect this cause will&H1; sort unto.
Tell on&H5; your case: of whence, and what is your name?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I am of Rochell, and my name Villiers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Of what profession?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: A Merchant I, my honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: But though you be a Merchant, I believe
Here is some ware you must not deal withal.
Thinkst thou Dyana, my dear Lord thy father,
Will&H1; know us&Htp; in&H4; this Sempsters poor disguise?

sp.speaker: Dya.
sp.l: Madam, I know not, for&H3; much time is past
Since he at Newkerk parted with us&Htp; last.
She must be widow if the Merchants wife,
But by&H4; this match I think he will&H1; hardly thrive.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Monsieur Villiers, you shall have Justice sir,
Speak in&H4; your cause you have free liberty.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: My Lord of Bulloigne, thus then stands my case,
This Gentlewoman whom my suit concerns,
Being embarked for&H4; England with her&H2; daughter,
To&H9; seek her&H2; husbands as she made report,
Twixt Sluice in&H4; Flanders where she went aboard,
And Goodwines Sands, by&H4; sturdy adverse winds,
Was beaten back upon&H4; the coast of Fraunce,
And came to&H4; Rochell, where my dwelling is.
I taking liking of her&H6;, entertained her&H6;,
Let her&H6; a house convenient as I thought,
And lent her&H6; money to&H9; supply her&H2; wants,
And afterwards won by&H4; affection,
I did solicit her&H6; in&H4; way of marriage,
But still she did defer me with delays,
Because she said her&H2; husband still did live:
But for&H4; my kindness if her&H2; husband died,
She told me then, I was the likest to&H9; speed.
She having got some money by&H4; her&H2; needle,
Desired me to&H9; let her&H6; have a lease:
The lease was drawn, to&H4; which&H61; she put her&H2; name
Widow, which&H61; here her&H2; own hand testifies:
Which&H61; being thus confessed by&H4; herself,
I by&H4; her&H2; promise claim her&H6; for&H4; my wife.
Lod.
The case is plain.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: That&H3; he shall go without me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Lady, what way have you to&H9; avoid this bond?
Here is your hand set to&H9; confirm the deed.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: But not my heart: and that&H62; I will&H1; be sworn.
Here is one I think, that&H61; hath had that&H62; too long
To&H9; leave it now, or else I have more wrong.
Unto the Scrivener I referred the same,
And he put that&H62; word, widow to&H4; my name.
I humbly do entreat your highness favour,
For&H3; if you knew where I had dwelt before,
I think you would do that&H62; for&H4; me, and more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Speak gentlewoman, where have you been bred?

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: I was attending in&H4; my younger years,
And this sweet Girl, though now thus mean and poor
Upon&H4; the Duchess, the Dukes wife of Bulloigne,
Though I say it, one that&H61; she loved once,
Whilst she did flourish in&H4; prosperity:
And had not fortune much impaired her&H2; state,
I had not now stood in&H4; such need of friends.
But when the greatest into danger falls,
The weakest still did go unto the walls.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It is very true, that&H3; have I tried myself,
Thy tears no&H2; longer can conceal my love.
Rise Oriana, rise my sweet Dyana,
Lodwicks true wife, and his right virtuous.
Embrace thy lost son Frederickonce more,
Whom we&Htp; supposed never to&H9; have seen.
With him receive a daughter, Brabants heir,
He hath been foster-father to&H4; thy boy,
And both are here to&H9; full complete our&Htp; joy.

sp.speaker: Oria.
sp.l: My dear Frederick?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My beloved brother?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O happy Frederick finding such a mother,
And such a sister, father, friends and all,
Never a man did better fortune fall.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How say you Monsieur Merchant? is your suite void
In&H4; law or no&H5;? is she a widow now?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: No&H7; my good Lord, and I rejoice thereat.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thanks, but we&Htp; will&H1; requite thy love and kindness
Extended to&H4; them in&H4; necessity:
And our&Htp; reward thou shalt have liberally.
What news with thee, thou comest in&H4; such haste:

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: His highness from his holy Pilgrimage
Is home returned, and doth require your presence.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That&H62; is but our&Htp; duty, welcome is our&Htp; King,
His highness now shall sentence traitorous Aniou,
According as his treacheries deserve,
And all our&Htp; joys shall be disclosed to&H4; him,
That&H61; have so&H51; happily this day befallen.
Thus time the saddest heart from sorrow calls,
And helps the weak, long thrust unto the walls.
